1
(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1977
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
1
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"I have the honor to announce that the October 1977 Term of the
Supreme Court of the United States is now convened."
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 76-1258. Peter Territo et al., appellants, v. Curtis Poche, Jr.,
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 76–1340. William R. Bonner, appellant, v. W. M. Blumenthal,
Secretary of the Treasury, et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the District of Columbia. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction.
No. 76–1488. Joe Jacobson, appellant, v. City of Tucson et al. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Arizona. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 76–1566. Roger H. Comly, appellant, v. Lower Southampton
Township. Appeal from the Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania,
Eastern District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 76-1674. Norman Stephenson et al., appellants, v. Department
of Agriculture and Consumer Services of Florida. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 76-1688. John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, ap-
pellant, v. Charles R. Brady, etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Mississippi. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 76-1714. Frank Rosenthal, appellant, v. Nevada et al. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Nevada. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
260-278-77-
-1

2
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1977
No. 76–1741. Donald Schupak et al., appellants, v. Forman &
Zuckerman, P. A. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of North Caro-
lina. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 76–1759. Daytona Beach Racing and Recreational Facilities
District et al., appellants, v. Volusia County et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 77-61. Dortha Leigh, widow and surviving joint tenant of
J. W. Leigh, appellant, v. Oklahoma ex rel. The Oklahoma Tax Com-
mission. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Oklahoma. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77–86. Charles Lester Gregg, appellant, v. Indiana. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Indiana. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77-125. Getty Oil Company, appellant, v. Oklahoma Tax
Commission. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Oklahoma. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77–133. Rufus Roland Faulk, appellant, v. Arkansas. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Arkansas. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77–181. Helen Corless, appellant, v. City of Lebanon. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Montgomery County. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77–202. In the Matter of Joseph M. Kadans, appellant. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Nevada. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 77-210. Eveandra Enterprises, Inc., appellant, v. County of
Nassau. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77–287. Otto W. Reel, Executor of the Estate of George Way-
land Evans, appellant, v. Iowa Department of Revenue. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Iowa. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 76-1563. Coca Cola Bottling Company of Puerto Rico, Inc.,
et al., appellants, v. Jose M. Alonso-Garcia, Manager, State Insurance
Fund, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Dis-
trict of Puerto Rico. Judgment affirmed.
No. 77–180. Robert W. Hagopian, appellant, v. Justices of the Su-
preme Judicial Court of Massachusetts. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the District of Massachusetts. Judgment
affirmed.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1977
3
No. 76–1634. Marcell Baer and Wesley A. Baer, Executors of the
Estate of Joseph R. Baer, appellants, v. Jennie Baer. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Utah. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question. Mr. Justice Stevens would note probable
jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 76–1647. Richard Alan Katzman. appellant, v. Florida. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Marshall and Mr. Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction
and set case for oral argument.
No. 76–1681. Otis Edward Golden, appellant, v. California. Ap-
peal from the Court of Appeal of California, Third Appellate Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Brennan would note probable juris-
diction and set case for oral argument.
No. 76–1699. Leadership Housing Inc., et al., appellants, v. Depart-
ment of Revenue of the State of Florida. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 76–1778. John C. Russell, appellant, v. City of Raytown, Mis-
souri. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Missouri, Kansas City
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari denied.
No. 76-1807. Genuine Parts Company and Sentry Insurance Com-
pany, appellants, v. Court of Appeals of the State of New Mexico and
Joe W. Wood. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Mexico. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
No. 76-1811. Robert J. Tracy, appellant, v. Ohio. Appeal from the
Court of Appeals of Ohio, Franklin County. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 76–1824. Fleming S. Jackson, appellant, v. Stone and Simons
Advertising Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of Michigan. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 76-6656. Maggie Allen, appellant, v. Virginia. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dismissed for want of

4
MONDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1977
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 76–6798. William Thomas Bates, Jr., appellant, v. Doretta Ann
Ince. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Oregon. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 76–6867. Samuel Corrado et ux., appellants, v. Providence Re-
development Agency. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Rhode
Island. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of cer-
tiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 76–6995. Joseph C. Johns, appellant, v. Jeffrey Haber. Appeal
from the Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari
denied.
No. 77-45. Robert Calhoun, Jr., appellant, v. New York et al. Ap-
peal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
No. 77-77. Howard J. O'Brien, Jr., Executor of the Estate of How-
ard J. O'Brien, deceased, and F. Stuart O'Brien, appellants, v. City
of Syracuse et al. Appeal from the Appellate Division of the Supreme
Court of New York, Fourth Judicial Department. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77–145. Edgar T. Crismon, appellant v. United States. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
No. 76–1704. W. E. Campbell, Superintendent of Public Instruc-
tion of Virginia, et al., appellants, v. Daniel J. Kruse et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Vir-
ginia. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Eastern District of Virginia with directions to
decide the claim based on the federal statute § 504 of the Federal Re-
habilitation Act of 1973. Westby v. Doe, 433 U.S. (1977). Mr. Jus-
tice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 76–1735. Marable-Pirkle, Inc., appellant, v. Ed Turner et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. Motion of appellee Ed
-

MONDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1977
10
5
Turner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 74-44. Barnes & Tucker Company, appellant, v. Pennsylvania.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Middle District.
Motion of National Coal Association et al. for leave to file a brief, as
amici curiae, granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice White would.
note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 77-84. Michael Smith et al., appellants, v. Board of Governors
of the University of North Carolina et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Western District of North Carolina.
Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall and
Mr. Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and set case for
oral argument.
No. 77–250. Americans United for the Separation of Church and
State et al., appellants, v. Ray Blanton, Governor of Tennessee, et al.
Appeal from the United States District for the Middle District of
Tennessee. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Mar-
shall and Mr. Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and
set case for oral argument.
No. 77-114. William J. Quirk and Leon E. Wein, appellants, v.
Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York et al.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. Motion of United
States Trust Company of New York for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 77–234. Richard E. Spencer, appellant, v. Lorraine Spencer
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Middle
District of North Carolina. The appeal is dismissed for want of ju-
risdiction. MTM Inc. v. Baxley, 420 U.S. 799 (1975).
No. 77–5216. Robert W. Townsley, appellant, v. Board of Port
Commissioners, Port of Oakland. Appeal from the Court of Appeal
of California, First Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a properly presented federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 76–1692. Donald Percy, Secretary, Wisconsin Department of
Health and Social Services, petitioner, v. Ronald Francis Terry aka
Barbara Lynn Terry. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Wisconsin. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin to con-

6
MONDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1977
sider whether its judgment is based upon federal or state constitutional
grounds, or both. See California v. Krivda, 409 U.S. 33 (1972).
No. 76–529. Montana Power Company et al., petitioners, v. United
States Environmental Protection Agency et al.;
No. 76-585. American Petroleum Institute et al., petitioners, v.
United States Environmental Protection Agency et al.;
No. 76–594. Indiana-Kentucky Electric Corporation et al., peti-
tioners, v. United States Environmental Protection Agency et al.;
No. 76-603. Alabama Power Company et al., petitioners, v. United
States Environmental Protection Agency et al.;
No. 76–619. Utah Power & Light Company et al., petitioners,
2. United States Environmental Protection Agency et al.; and
No. 76–620. Western Energy Supply and Transmission Associates
et al.; petitioners, v. United States Environmental Protection Agency
et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the District of Columbia Circuit. Motion of Solicitor General to dis-
miss writs of certiorari as improvidently granted denied. Judgment
vacated and cases remanded to Court of Appeals for further considera-
tion in light of Clean Air Act Amendments of 1977, Pub. L. 95–95, and
to consider the suggestion of mootness filed by the intervenor-respond-
ents. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision
of this motion and cases.

No. 75-718. East Texas Motor Freight System, Inc., petitioner,

or decision of this motion.

Donald. Respondent requested to file response to petition for rehear-
ing within thirty days. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this order.
No. 76-811. Regents of the University of California, petitioner,
v. Allan Bakke. Motion of State of California for leave to participate
in oral argument, as amicus curiae, denied. Motion of Solicitor Gen-
eral for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of
Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus
curiae, granted and fifteen additional minutes allotted for that pur-
pose. Motion of Pacific Legal Foundation for leave to participate in
oral argument, as amicus curiae, denied. Motion of petitioner for addi-
tional time for oral argument granted and fifteeen additional minutes
allotted for that purpose. Respondent allotted fifteen additional min-
utes for oral argument. Motion of Chamber of Commerce of the
United States for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus
curiae, denied. Motion of NAACP Legal Defense and Educational
Fund, Inc., for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae,
denied.

and Welfare, et al. Motion for clarification and recall of judgment
denied.

that there is no final judgment within the meaning of 28 U.S.C. 1257.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1977
No. 77-5083. James Adams, petitioner, v. Florida. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied;
No. 77-5099. Rebecca A. Smith, aka Rebecca A. Machetti, peti-
tioner, v. Georgia. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court
Georgia denied;
No. 77–5155. William Neal Moore, petitioner, v. Georgia. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia denied; and
No. 77-5288. Robert A. Sullivan, Gary E. Alvord and Learie L.
Alford, petitioners, v. Reubin O'D. Askew, etc., et al. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied. Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall, dissenting:
Adhering to our views that the death penalty is in all circumstances
cruel and unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth and Four-
teenth Amendments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231 (1976),
we would grant certiorari and vacate the death sentences in these
cases.
No. 76-6738. James F. Heimerle, petitioner, v. United States. Mo-
tion for leave to file supplement to petition granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit denied.
No. 76-6802. Leon Carmichael, petitioner, v. Alabama. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama de-
nied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant cer-
tiorari even though the denial of the petition is without prejudice to
the filing of a petition for writ of habeas corpus in the appropriate
United States District Court.
No. 76–6834. Melvin J. Blackmon, petitioner, v. Louie L. Wain-
wright, Secretary, Florida Department of Offender Rehabilitation.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida de-
nied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant
certiorari.

Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division, denied. Mr. Justice Brennan
and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant certiorari.

No. 77–239. Marshallton-McKean School District, petitioner, v.
Brenda Evans et. al. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit denied. The Chief Jus-
tice, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist would grant the
petitions for writs of certiorari, vacate the judgment and remand
cases to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of
Dayton Board of Education v. Brinkman, 433 U.S. — (1977). Mr.
Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of these petitions.

260-278-77—10

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1977
131
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr.
Justice Stevens.
Mr. Solicitor General McCree presented the Honorable Griffin B.
Bell, Attorney General of the United States.
The Chief Justice said:
"Mr. Attorney General, the Court welcomes you to the performance
of the important duties which devolve upon you as the chief law officer
of the Government, and as an officer of this Court. Your commission
will be recorded by the Clerk."
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 76-1418. County Board of Arlington County, Virginia, et al.,
petitioners, v. Rudolph A. Richards et al. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Virginia. Motion of D.C. Federa-
tion of Civic Associations et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae,
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment set aside
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Virginia for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
per curiam. Mr. Justice Marshall would grant certiorari and set case
for oral argument.
No. 76-1526. Southern & Northern Overlying Carrier Chapters
of the California Dump Truck Owners Association, appellant, v. Pub-
lic Utilities Commission of California. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of California. The appeal is dismissed without prejudice to
appellant's raising of any appropriate federal claims following the
completion of the additional proceedings. See Boston & Maine Rail-
road v. United States, 358 U.S. 68 (1958). Opinion per curiam. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 76-265. Massachusetts et al., appellants, v. Helen B. Feeney.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
260-278-77-11

132
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1977
Massachusetts. Motion of John R. Buckley, Secretary of Administra-
tion and Finance of Massachusetts, for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the District of Massachusetts for further
consideration in light of Washington v. Davis, 426 U.S. 229 (1976).
Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Powell
would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 76–1828. H. D. Gross, dba Valley Rock and Sand Corporation,
appellant, v. Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate Dis-
trict. Appeal from Supreme Court of California. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 76–6962. Valerie A. Witzkowski, appellant, v. Illinois. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77-5145. Gladys Royal, appellant, v. Bob Bergland et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Columbia. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77–292. United States Postal Service, petitioner, v. Associated
Third Class Mail Users. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of the March
1977 amended provisions of the Board of Governors' internal operat-
ing procedures.

No. D-109. In the Matter of Disbarment of George Raymond
Speckman. Disbarment entered.
No. D-115. In the Matter of Disbarment of Oliver J. McCarron.
It is ordered that Oliver J. McCarron, of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within 40 days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-116. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard William But-
ler. It is ordered that Richard William Butler, of Glenarm, Mary-
land, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within 40 days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-117. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert A. Eisenberg.
It is ordered that Robert A. Eisenberg, of Beverly Hills, California, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within 40 days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-118. In the Matter of Disbarment of Marshall Jack Rutten-
berg. It is ordered that Marshall Jack Ruttenberg, of Wilmette, Illi-
nois, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within 40 days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

of Sheffield, Alabama, et al. Argued by Mr. Drew S. Days, III, for

Navarette, Jr. Argued by Mr. Sanford Svetcov for the petitioners and
by Mr. Michael E. Adams for the respondent.

cation for stay of the order of the Supreme Court of South Dakota
(No. 11826), dated September 9, 1977, presented to Mr. Justice Black-

MONDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1977
151
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Powell,
Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 76–1349. Edward W. Maher, etc., et al., appellants, v. Mary
Buckner et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Connecticut. Motion of appellees for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. Judgment affirmed.
No. 76–1519. Alfred O. Kuhnle, appellant, v. John T. O'Hagan,
as Commissioner of the Fire Department of the City of New York, et
al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 76–1813. Linda Marie Thompson, appellant, v. Washington.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Washington. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77–280. Paul Koch Volkswagen, Inc., appellant, v. William
Wisherd. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Oregon. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77–295. Eileen Rafferty et al., appellants, v. John Marcin.
Appeal from the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-147. Rafael Olivera et al., applicants, v. South Carolina.
Application for reduction of bond, presented to Mr. Justice Marshall
and by him referred to the Court, denied.
No. A-327. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey et al.,
applicants, v. British Airways Board et al. Application for stay, pre-
sented to Mr. Justice Marshall and by him referred to the Court,
denied.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1977
No. D-64. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jack Seymour Wasser-
man. Disbarment entered.
No. D-108. In the Matter of Disbarment of Charles D. Zeigler.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-110. In the Matter of Disbarment of Chester Thomas Cruze.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-112. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kenneth R. Cain. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-113. In the Matter of Disbarment of Burton A. Librach.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-114. In the Matter of Disbarment of Anthony V. Consol-
dane. It is ordered that Anthony V. Consoldane, of Warren, Ohio, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-119. In the Matter of Disbarment of Manuel Jerome Sugar.
It is ordered that Manuel Jerome Sugar, of Olympia Fields, Illinois, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D–120. In the Matter of Disbarment of Peter William Boznos.
It is ordered that Peter William Boznos, of Pompano Beach, Florida,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why
he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 75-1771. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, petitioner, v.
Standard Life & Accident Insurance Company. Motion to retax costs
granted. Mr. Justice Stewart took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this motion.
No. 76–811. Regents of the University of California, petitioner, v.
Allan Bakke. Motion of Members of The Congressional Black Caucus
et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, denied. Each party to this
cause is directed to file within 30 days a supplemental brief discussing
Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 as it applies to this case.
No. 76–1143. Ray Marshall, Secretary of Labor, et al., appellants,
v. Barlow's, Inc. Motion of The Mountain States Legal Foundation
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
No. 76-1159. Arthur F. Quern, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Venus
Mandley et al.;
No. 76–1416. Joseph A. Califano, Jr., Secretary of Health, Edu-
cation, and Welfare, petitioner, v. Venus Mandley et al. Motion of

United Way of Metropolitan Chicago et al. for leave to file a brief, as
amici curiae, granted. Joint motion of petitioners for additional time

that purpose. Respondents allotted fifteen additional minutes for oral
argument.

CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 76-1410. Joseph V. Agosto, petitioner, v. Immigration and
Naturalization Service. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United.
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 76–1607. Securities and Exchange Commission, petitioner, v.
Samuel H. Sloan. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit granted. In addition to the
questions presented by the petition the parties are requested to brief
and argue the question of the possibility of mootness.

et al. Motion of respondents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and

of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for

MONDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1977
159
No. 76-6612. LaQuain Larry Scott, petitioner, v. Bill Williams
et al.; and
No. 76-6858. Michael Loice Lay, petitioner, v. Bill Williams et al.
Petitions for writs of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of
Oklahoma denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 76-6916. Roy Schuster, petitioner, v. New York. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec-
ond Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan, dissenting:
This suit is brought by a New York Citizen against New York offi-
cials. In that circumstance it is my view that New York may not in-
voke the Eleventh Amendment, since that amendment in terms bars.
only federal court suits against states by citizens of other states. Edel-
man v. Jordan, 415 U.S. 651, 687 (1974) (Brennan, J., dissenting).
I would grant petition and reverse judgment.
Mr. Justice Marshall would grant certiorari.
No. 77-119. Sophie Ruskay et al., petitioners, v. Chauncey L. Wad-
dell et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 77–128. Clarence O. Dupuy, Jr., petitioner, v. Milton E.
Dupuy. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice White.
No. 77–348. Richard T. Tracy, Sr., petitioner, v. Rodger A. Gol-
ston et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit and for other relief denied.
No. 77–5257. John Edward Rust, petitioner, v. Nebraska; Richard
D. Holtan, petitioner, v. Nebraska. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the Supreme Court of Nebraska denied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr.
Justice Marshall, dissenting:
Adhering to our views that the death penalty is in all circumstances
cruel and unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth and Four-
teenth Amendments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231 (1976),
we would grant certiorari and vacate the death sentences in this case.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITIONS FOR WRITS OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 77–373. Alan Ernest, petitioner, v. United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit; and

denied.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, OCTOBER, 20 1977
171
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Jus-
tice Powell, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
ORDER IN PENDING CASES
No. 77-452. Mobil Alaska Pipeline Company, petitioner, v.
United States et al.;
No. 77-457. Exxon Pipeline Company, petitioner, v. United States
et al.; and
No. 77-551. BP Pipelines Inc., petitioner, v. United States et al.
Applications for stay, presented to Mr. Justice Powell and by him re-
ferred to the Court, granted. Order of the Interstate Commerce Com-
mission served June 28, 1977, in its Investigation and Suspension
Docket No. 9164, Trans-Alaska Pipeline System (Rate Filings) hereby
stayed pending final disposition of the petitions for certiorari by this
Court. Stays conditioned upon applicants'-petitioners' agreement to
keep account of the amounts collected under the proposed rates, as
that term is used in the order in this matter issued by the Interstate
Commerce Commission on June 28, 1977, and their agreement to re-
fund any portion of the amounts collected under such rates by virtue
of the stay which it is ultimately determined that they were not law-
fully entitled to collect. Parties shall submit a proposed order em-
bodying this undertaking to the Clerk of this Court within five days.
Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this order.
260-278-77 -- -16

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1977
173
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION FOR CURIAM
No. 76–1640. General Atomic Company, petitioner, v. Edwin L.
Felter, etc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of New Mexico. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judg-
ment reversed, and case remanded to the Supreme Court of New
Mexico for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice Blackmun would not dis-
pose of this case summarily but would grant certiorari and hear argu-
ment. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 76–1809. John L. Scott, appellant, v. John D. Benn, Jr., et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77–395. John E. Bullion, appellant, v. City of Philadelphia.
Appeal from the Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77-5009. Shirley E. Hall, appellant, v. Russell F. Hall. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77-5055. D, a minor child, appellant, v. Juvenile Department
of Multnomah County. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Oregon.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 76–1834. Milton G. Klein, Director of Idaho Department of
Health and Welfare, et al., appellants, v. Jane Doe et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the District of Idaho. Motion of
appellees for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
District of Idaho for further consideration in light of Beal v. Doe, 431
260-278-77—17

174
U.S.
MONDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1977
(1977) and Maher v. Roe, 432 U.S.
(1977). Sepa-
rate opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 76-1855. Spencer Press, Inc., appellant, v. Jerome Kurtz, Com-
missioner of Internal Revenue of the United States. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts. Judg-
ment affirmed. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
No. 76-6870. Harold A. Schneider et al., appellants, v. Harlan
McNutt, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Western District of Washington. Judgment affirmed.
No. 77-18. Guy Osceola, appellant, v. Jerome K. Kuykendall et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Columbia. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist concur. See MTM Inc. v. Baxley, 420 U.S. 799 (1975) and
Gonazlez v. Automatic Employees Credit Union 419 U.S. 90 (1974).
The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Stevens would
affirm judgment.
No. 77–69. Robert A. Panora, Registrar of Motor Vehicle of Massa-
chusetts, appellant, v. Donald E. Montrym et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court
for the District of Massachusetts for further consideration in light of
Dixon v. Love, 431 U.S. 105 (1977).
No. 77–359. FLR Corporation, appellant, v. Bill Blodgett et al.
Appeal from the Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Eighth Supreme
Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77–336. Delta Air Lines, Inc., petitioner, v. James McBride. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
consideration in light of East Texas Motor Freight System, Inc. v.
Rodriquez, 431 U.S. 395 (1977).

MONDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1977
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
175
A-331. Russell C. Means, applicant, v. South Dakota. Order here-
tofore entered on October 14, 1977, vacated and application for stay
of order of Supreme Court of South Dakota, dated September 9, 1977,
denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun, joined by Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice Marshall, being concerned about the First Amendment
implications of the vacation of stay, dissents and would continue the
stay pending plenary consideration of the South Dakota Supreme
Court's revocation of the applicant's bail.
No. D-45. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Newton Mitchell.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-48. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Daniel Ehrlich-
man, Disbarment entered.
No. 74, Original. State of Georgia, plaintiff, v. State of South
Carolina. Motion for leave to file bill of complaint granted and de-
fendant shall have 60 days to answer.
No. 75-1870. E. I. duPont de Nemours and Company et al., peti-
tioners, v, Richard J. Collins et al.; and
No. 75–1872. Securities and Exchange Commission, petitioner, v.
Richard J. Collins, Jr., et al. Motion to retax costs denied. Mr. Justice
Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 76–749. Pfizer, Inc., et al., petitioners, v. Government of India
et al. Motion of Federal Republic of Germany for leave to participate
in oral argument, as amicus curiae, denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 76-938. Federal Maritime Commission et al., petitioners, v.
Pacific Maritime Association et al. Motion of respondents for divided
argument granted.
No. 76-944. Richard Nixon, petitioner, v. Warner Communica-
tions, Inc., et al. Motion of respondents for divided argument granted.
No. 76–1114. California et al., petitioners, v. Southland Royalty
Company et al.;
No. 76–1133. El Paso Natural Gas Company, petitioner, v. South-
land Royalty Company et al.; and
No. 76–1587. Federal Power Commission, petitioner, v. Southland
Royalty Company et al. Motion of Federal Power Commission for
additional time for oral argument granted and fifteen additional min-
utes allotted for that purpose. Respondents allotted fifteen additional
minutes for oral argument. Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Powell
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

176
MONDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1977
No. 76–1168. Arizona, Richard Boykin, Sheriff, Pima County,
petitioner, v. George Washington, Jr. Motion of respondent for ap-
pointment of counsel granted and it is ordered that Ed Bolding, Es-
quire, of Tucson, Arizona, is appointed to serve as counsel for re-
spondent in this case.
No. 76–1310. Thomas L. Houchins, Sheriff of the County of
Alameda, California, petitioner, v. KQED, Inc., et al. Motion of The
Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press Legal Defense and
Research Fund, et al., for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, denied.
Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of
this motion.
No. 76-1596. United States, petitioner, v. John Mauro and John
Fusco. Motion of respondent John Mauro for leave to proceed further
herein in forma pauperis granted.
No. 76–1800. United States, petitioner, v. Onofre J. Sotelo and
Naomi Sotelo. Motion of petitioner for leave to dispense with print-
ing appendix granted.
No. 76–6942. Ensio Ruben Lakeside, petitioner, v. Oregon. Motion
of petitioner for appointment of counsel granted, it is ordered that
Phillip M. Margolin, Esquire, of Portland, Oregon, is appointed to
serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 77-324. Sidney S. Hicklin et al., appellants, v. Edmund
Orbeck, Commissioner of the Department of Labor of Alaska, et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Alaska. In this case probable
jurisdiction noted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Powell
would grant certiorari, vacate judgment and remand case to the Court
of Appeals for further consideration in light of Dayton Board of

no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.

No. 77–5019. Nelson Perez, petitioner, v. United States. Petition

Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Stewart would grant certiorari.
No. 77-5026. Johnny Paul Witt, petitioner, v. Florida. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied;
No. 77-5305. James Paul Burns, petitioner, v. Texas. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas denied;
No. 77-5355. John Charles Shippy, petitioner, 2. Texas. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas
denied; and
No. 77-5464. Leonard Pryor, petitioner, v. Georgia. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia denied. Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall, dissenting: Adhering to our views
that the death penalty is in all circumstances cruel and unusual
punishment prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments,
Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231 (1976), we would grant certi-
orari and vacate the death sentences in these cases.

tions of Peter Lincoln Russo, Jr.; Bobby de la Cruz; Donald James

199
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Before hearing argument this morning I have an announcement
for the Journal of the Court. Major General Rowland F. Kirks, Re-
tired, long a member of the Bar of this Court and Director of the Ad-
ministrative Office of the United States Courts since 1970, died early
this morning. General Kirks was appointed by this Court as Director
seven years ago and in that position he has given outstanding and
dedicated service to the Judiciary."

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1977
201
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 76–6194. Peter Rinaldi, petitioner, v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and
petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the United States District Court for the Southern Dis-
trict of Florida for the purpose of dismissing the indictment. Opinion
per curiam. Mr. Chief Justice Burger dissents. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Justice White joins.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 76–1644. J. B. Gunn, Warden, petitioner, v. Michael D. Poulin.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted,
judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther consideration in light of Wainwright v. Sykes, 433 U.S.—
(1977).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-222. Otis Bobby Mecom, applicant, v. United States. Applica-
tion for reduction of bail, presented to Mr. Justice Brennan and by
him referred to the Court, denied.
No. A-332. Mark Gilbert et al., applicants, v. George N. Leighton,
Judge, etc., et al. Application for stay of injunction, presented to Mr.
Justice White and by him referred to the Court, denied.
No. D-121. In the Matter of Disbarment of George John Skontos.
It is ordered that George John Skontos. of Chicago, Ill., be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, return-
260-278-77—21

202
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1977
able within 40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 76–1596. United States, petitioner, v. John Mauro and John
Fusco. Motion for appointment of counsel granted and it is ordered
that Kevin Ross, Esquire, of Kew Gardens, New York, is appointed
to serve as counsel for the respondents in this case.
No. 76–1767. National Society of Professional Engineers, peti-
tioner, c. United States. Motion of petitioner for leave to file Court
of Appeals appendix in lieu of an appendix as prescribed by Rule 39
of the Rules of this Court granted.
No. 77-526. George A. Chitty, petitioner, v. United States; Robert
Morris Postal, petitioner, v. United States. Application for bail, pre-
sented to Mr. Justice Brennan and by him referred to the Court,
denied.
No. 77–5353. Rufus Junior Mincey, petitioner, v. Arizona. Appli-

to Mr. Justice Brennan and by him referred to the Court, denied.
No. 77-5431. Melvin Leroy Tyler, petitioner, v. Leslie Dyer, Clerk,
Circuit Court of Platte County. Application for stay of the state
court proceedings, presented to Mr. Justice Marshall and by him re-
ferred to the Court, denied.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 77–262. Duke Power Company, appellant, v. Carolina Envi-
ronmental Study Group. Inc., et al.; and
No. 77–375. United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission et al.,
appellants, c. Carolina Environmental Study Group, Inc., et al. Ap-
peals from the United States District Court for the Western District
of North Carolina. Motion of Pacific Legal Foundation for leave to
file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of Southeastern Legal
Foundation for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. In
these cases probable jurisdiction noted. Cases consolidated and a total
of 1 hour allotted for oral argument.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-471. Donald C. McDougal, appellant, v. County of Im-
perial. Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77–502. Stephen Muss et al., appellants, v. City of Miami Beach,
etc. Appeal from the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 76–1377. Oregon State Penitentiary et al., petitioners, v.
Jerry Hammer. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme.
Court of Oregon. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Oregon for re-
consideration in light of Dixon v. Love, 431 U.S. 105 (1977). Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with whom Mr. Justice Brennan,
Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 77–277. Allen Aaron Jackson, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Claims.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the United States Court of Claims for further considera-
tion in light of the position presently asserted by the Solicitor General
in his brief filed October 25, 1977. Mr. Justice Rehnquist would deny
the petition.
No. 77–5161. Kurk Kendall Johnson, petitioner, v. Don H. Hamp-
ton, District Judge, Tenth Judicial District of Oklahoma. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case re-
260-278-77-24

220
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1977
manded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma for further
consideration in light of Brown v. Ohio, 432 U.S. - (1977) and Har-
ris v. Oklahoma, 433 U.S. (1977).

No. D-100. In the Matter of Disbarment of Owen Jennings Ooms.
Owen Jennings Ooms, of Chicago, Illinois, having requested to resign
as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be
stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar
of this Court. The rule to show cause heretofore issued on April 4,
1977, is hereby discharged.

Disbarment entered.

tioners, v. The Suquamish Indian Tribe et al. Motion of Solicitor Gen-

No. 77-26. Elizabeth Jane Young Chin, petitioner, v. United
States; and
No. 77-32. Kenneth Chin, petitioner, v. United States. Application
for an order directing the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec-
ond Circuit to issue a printed opinion, presented to Mr. Justice Mar-
shall and by him referred to the Court, denied.
No. 77-452. Mobil Alaska Pipeline Company, petitioner, v. United
States et al.;
No. 77-457. Exxon Pipeline Company, petitioner, v. United States
et al.;
No. 77-551. BP Pipelines Inc., petitioner, v. United States et al.;
No. 77–602. Arco Pipe Line Company, petitioner, v. United States
et al.
On October 20, 1977, this Court stayed the order of the Interstate
Commerce Commission served June 28, 1977, in its Investigation and
Suspension Docket No. 9164, Trans-Alaska Pipeline System (Rate
Filings) pending final disposition of the petitions for writs of cer-
tiorari by this Court. To further effectuate that order, it is hereby
ordered:
1. During the period the stay is in effect, commencing at 3 p.m.
E. D. T., October 20, 1977, the following pipeline companies may col-
lect their respective rates set forth in the tariffs that were suspended
by the Interstate Commerce Commission in its order of June 28, 1977:
Amerada Hess Pipeline Corporation
Arco Pipeline Company

222
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1977
BP Pipeline Company
Mobil Alaska Pipeline Company
Sohio Pipe Line Company
Exxon Pipeline Company
Union Alaska Pipeline Company
2. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission may proceed with
its investigation of the rates set forth in said tariffs (FERC Docket
No. (R78-1)) and in connection with that investigation may enter any
appropriate orders not inconsistent with either this order or this
Court's order of October 20, 1977.
3. During the period the stay is in effect, the pipeline companies
shall keep account of all sums collected under the terms of said tariffs
by virtue of the stay entered by this Court.
4. In the event certiorari is denied or it is otherwise ultimately de-
termined that said pipeline companies were not lawfully entitled to
collect a portion of the rates so collected, the pipeline companies shall
refund such portion of said rates, with interest computed in accord-
ance with Section 15 (8) (e) of the Interstate Commerce Act (49
U.S.C. § 15 (8) (e)), to the persons entitled thereto without further
order of this Court.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice
Marshall joins. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Mr.
Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Powell took part in the consideration
or decision of this order.
No
No. 77-5353. Rufus Junior Mincey, petitioner, v. Arizona. Motion
of petitioner for appointment of counsel granted and it is ordered
that Richard Oseran, Esquire, of Tucson, Arizona, is appointed to
serve as counsel in this case.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1977
229
No. 77-5488. Joseph James Blake, petitioner, v. Georgia. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia; and
No. 77-5538. John A. Spenkelink, etc., petitioner, v. Florida. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied. Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall, dissenting: Adhering to our
views that the death penalty is in all circumstances cruel and unusual
punishment prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.
Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231 (1976), we would grant cer-
tiorari and vacate the death sentences in these cases.

OPINION
No. 76–1057. John W. Key et al., appellants, v. Michael M. Doyle
et al. Appeal from the District of Columbia Court of Appeals. Appeal
dismissed for lack of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
White with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Blackmun
and Mr. Justice Powell join.
Adjourned until Monday, November 28, 1977, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1977
243
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Powell,
Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 76–1588. Joseph A. Califano, Jr., Secretary of Health, Educa-
tion and Welfare, appellant, v. Ruth McMahon. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York.
Motion of appellee for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the Eastern District of New York for further consideration
in light of Califano v. Jobst, 434 U.S. (1977). Mr. Justice Blackmun
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
-
No. 77-419. Houston Belt & Terminal Railway Company, appel-
lant, v. Joe W. Wherry. Appeal from the Court of Civil Appeals of
Texas, First Supreme Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice
Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 77-5502. Samuel Douglas, appellant, v. United States et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Cir-
cuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
No. 77–5269. Jimmie L. Simpson, appellant, v. Florida. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this case.
No. 77-5561. William Eugene Jones, appellant, v. Colorado. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Colorado. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Blackmun took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
260-278-77—26

244
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1977
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-53. Marie Pierre et al., petitioners, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals to consider
the question of mootness. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 77–5069. William Earl Nunley, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court for
the Western District of Tennessee with directions to dismiss the in-
dictment. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 75-1690. James Parham, Individually and as Commissioner of
Department of Human Resources, et al., appellants, v. J. L. and J. R.,
minors, etc. Motion of Solicitor General for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, granted. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 76–419. Vermont Yankee Nuclear Power Corporation, peti-
tioner, v. Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc., et al.; and
No. 76–528. Consumers Power Company, petitioner, v. Nelson
Aeschliman et al. Motion of the Attorney General of New York for
leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, denied. Mr.
Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion.
No. 76–811. Regents of the University of California, petitioner,
v. Allan Bakke. Motion of Solicitor General for leave to file a supple-
mental brief after argument, as amicus curiae, granted. Mr. Justice
Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 76–1359. Bankers Trust Company, petitioner, v. Samuel Mallis
and Franklyn Kupferman. Motion of Solicitor General for leave to
file a brief, as amucus curiae, granted. Motion of Solicitor General for
leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, granted. Mr.
Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of
these motions.
No. 77-533. Angelo Hisquierdo, petitioner, v. Jess H. Hisquierdo.
Solicitor General invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views
of the United States. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this matter.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1977
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
245
No. 77-404. City of Philadelphia et al., appellants, v. New Jersey
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. In this case
probable jurisdiction noted. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in
the consideration or decision of this matter.
No. 77–653. William Swisher et al., appellants, v. Donald Brady
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District.
of Maryland. Motion of appellees for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris granted. In this case probable jurisdiction noted. Mr. Justice
Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this matter.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 77–380. Cecil D. Andrus, Secretary of the Interior, petitioner,
v. Charlestone Stone Products Co., Inc. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision
of this petition.
No. 77–452. Mobil Alaska Pipeline Company, petitioner, v. United
States et al.;
No. 77-457. Exxon Pipeline Company, petitioner, v. United States
et al.;
No. 77–551. BP Pipelines Inc., petitioner, v. United States et al.;
and
No. 77–602. ARCO Pipe Line Company, petitioner, v. United
States et al. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted. Cases consolidated
and a total of one hour allotted for oral argument. Mr. Justice Stew-
art, Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of these petitions.
No. 77-5549. Michael Taylor, petitioner, v. Kentucky. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Kentucky granted. Mr.
Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion and petition.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 76–1776. Roosevelt Peabody, petitioner v. United States;
No. 76–6907. Raymond Cason, petitioner, v. United States; and
No. 76–6926. Harry Tharp, petitioner, v. United States. Petitions
for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
consideration or decision of these petitions.

No. 77-5450. Jose Jesus Ceja, petitioner, v. Arizona. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona denied; and
No. 77-5482. Timothy W. McCorquodale, petitioner, v. Leroy
Stynchcombe et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Georgia denied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Mar-
shall, dissenting: Adhering to our views that the death penalty is in all
circumstances cruel and unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth
and Fourteenth Amendments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231
(1976), we would grant certiorari and vacate the death sentences in
these cases. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or
decision of these petitions.

to the Court, denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this petition and application.

No. 77-118. Pacific Engineering & Production Company of
Nevada, petitioner, v. Kerr-McGee Corporation and Kerr-McGee
Chemical Corporation. Petition for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration
or decision of this petition.
No. 77-5246. Gary F. Watson, petitioner, v. United States. Motion
to reject respondent's lodging and petition for rehearing denied. Mr.
Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion and petition.

latory Commission in support of petitioners, by Mr. Charles A. Horsky
for the petitioner in No. 76-528, by Mr. Richard E. AYRESfor the re-
spondents in No. 76-419, and by Mr. Myron M. Cherry for the re-
spondents in No. 76–528.

D. Massey, Superintendent, Union Correctional Institution. Argued by

vice, by special leave of Court.

No. 76-1095. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, petitioner, v.
Robert J. Kowalski et ux. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Bren-
nan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr.
Chief Justice Burger joins.

On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Tenth Circuit. Judgment affirmed by an equally divided Court. Opin-
ion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice
Stewart took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1977
277
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Powell,
Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 76–1291. Idaho Department of Employment, petitioner, v.
Marlene G. Smith. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Idaho. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment re-
versed, and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Idaho for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
per curiam. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan dissenting in part with whom Mr. Justice Mar-
shall joins. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens dissenting in part.
No. 76–1830. Pennsylvania, petitioner, v. Harry Mimms. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania,
Eastern District. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania,
Eastern District, for further proceedings not inconsistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 76–1847. Shelby County, Tennessee, et al., appellants, v.
Edward B. Peel. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Mid-
dle Division. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 77-5321. Thomas L. Grimes, appellant, v. Patricia L. Miller
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Middle
District of North Carolina. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Blackmun
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
260-278-77-30

278
MONDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1977
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 76-1243. United States, petitioner, v. Tony M. Smith and
Nellie Smith. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further consideration in light of Commissioner of Internal Reve-
nue v. Kowalski, 434 U.S. (1977). Mr. Justice Blackmun took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.

vember 10, 1977, presented to Mr. Justice Powell and by him referred
to the Court, granted pending the timely filing and disposition of an
appeal in this Court. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this application.
No. D-65. In the Matter of Disbarment of Samuel Gallant. Dis-
barment entered. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this order.
No. D-104. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard C. Murray.
Disbarment entered. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this order.
No. D-122. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joseph E. Stillo. It is
ordered that Joseph E. Stillo of Chicago, Illinois, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no
part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. D–123. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jerry F. Chvosta. It is
ordered that Jerry F. Chvosta of North Randall, Ohio, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Mr. Justice Blackmun
took no part in the consideration or decision of this order.

returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Mr.
Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this
order.

No. 76-1200. Roger Crist, as Warden of the Montana State Peni-
tentiary, Deer Lodge, Montana, et al., appellants, v. Merrel Cline and
L. R. Bretz. Case restored to calendar for reargument. Counsel re-
quested to brief and discuss during oral argument the following
questions.
1. Is the rule heretofore applied in the federal courts-that jeopardy
attaches in jury trials when the jury is sworn-constitutionally man-
dated?

280
MONDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1977
2. Should this Court hold that the Constitution does not require
jeopardy to attach in any trial-state or federal, jury or nonjury--
until the first witness is sworn?
The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief expressing the views
of the United States on each of these questions.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
No. 76-1484. James Zurcher, etc., et al., petitioners, v. The Stan-
ford Daily et al.; and
No. 76–1600. Louis P. Bergna, District Attorney, and Craig
Brown, petitioners, v. The Stanford Daily et al. Motion of petitioners
for additional time for oral argument denied. Alternative request for
divided argument granted. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 76–1608. Michigan, petitioner, v. Loren Tyler and Robert
Tompkins. Motion of L. Brooks Patterson, Esquire, to permit Jeffrey
Butler, Esquire, to present oral argument, pro hac vice, on behalf of
petitioner granted. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this motion.

No. 77–56. In the Matter of Edna Smith, appellant. Motion of

ORDERS
It is ordered that William E. Foley be appointed Director of the
Administrative Office of the United States Courts, effective Novem-
ber 21, 1977, pursuant to the provisions of § 601 of Title 28 of the
United States Code.
It is ordered that Joseph F. Spaniol be appointed Deputy Director
of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts, effective

288
MONDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1977
November 21, 1977, pursuant to the provisions of § 601 of Title 28 of
the United States Code.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, December 12, 1977, until
Monday, January 9, 1978.

OPINIONS
No. 75–536. Nashville Gas Company, petitioner, v. Nora D. Satty.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part and vacated in part and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist in which Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr.
Justice White and Mr. Justice Blackmun join and in Part I of which
Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Powell
join. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in the result and con-
current in part with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
Marshall join. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens concurring in the
judgment.
No. 76-616. New York, appellant, v. Cathedral Academy. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of New York. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals of New York for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Stewart. Dissenting statement by Mr. Chief Justice Burger
and Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White.
No. 75-1069. Richmond Unified School District et al., petitioners,
v. Sonja Lynn Berg, etc. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light
260-278-77—32

296
TUESDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1977
of General Electric Co. v. Gilbert, 429 U.S. 125 (1976) and Nashville
Gas Co. v. Satty, ante, and for consideration of possible mootness.
Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 76–1149. John D. Carey et al., petitioners, v. Jarius Piphus,
etc., et al. Argued by Mr. Earl B. Hoffenberg for the petitioners and
by Mr. John S. Elson for the respondents.
No. 75–1690. James Parham, Individually and as Commissioner of
Department of Human Resources, et al., appellants, v. J. L. and J. R.,
minors, etc. Argued by Mr. R. Douglas Lackey for the appellants and
by Mr. John L. Cromartie, Jr. for the appellees.
No. 76–1346. Lorillard, a Division of Loew's Theatres, Inc., peti-
tioner, v. Frances P. Pons, Argued by Mr. Thornton H. Brooks for
the petitioner and by Mr. Norman B. Smith for the respondent.
No. 76–1500. Massachusetts, petitioner, v. United States. Argued
by Mr. Terence P. O'Malley for the petitioner and by Mr. Allan A.
Ryan, Jr. for the respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

OPINION
No. 76–835. United States, petitioner, v. New York Telephone
Company. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White joined by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr.
Justice Rehnquist, and in Parts I, II and III, of which Mr. Justice
Stewart joins, and in Part II of which Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall and Mr. Justice Stevens join. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart concurring in part and dissenting in part. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Stevens dissenting in part with whom Mr. Justice Brennan
and Mr. Justice White join and in part II of which Justice Stewart
joins.

respondent International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

19
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77–132. Sharon Hill, appellant, v. David Max Garner. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Oregon. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice White with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 77–578. Marion Wendell Briggs, appellant, v. North Carolina.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Cir-
cuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
No. 77–5329. Randy Standow, appellant, v. City of Spokane. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Washington. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Blackmun took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
Robert W. Blanchette et al., Trustees of Property of
Penn Central Transportation Company et al., applicants, v. United
States Railway Association et al. Appeals dismissed without prejudice
it appearing that the appeals would not be in the interest of an ex-
peditious conclusion to the proceedings. Mr. Justice Blackmun took
no part in the consideration or decision of the appeals.

and Urban Development, et al., applicants, v. Myrna Underwood et al.

on October 18, 1976, denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion.

bail, presented to Mr. Justice Brennan and by him referred to the

the consideration or decision of this petition.

260-278-77-35

308
MONDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1977
Foundation for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
consideration or decision of these motions and petition.
No. 77-5553. Kenneth Albert Brock, petitioner, v. Texas. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas
denied; and
No. 77-5620. John Young, petitioner, v. Georgia. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia denied. Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall, dissenting: Adhering to our views
that the death penalty is in all circumstances cruel and unusual punish-
ment prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, Gregg
v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231 (1976), we would grant certiorari
and vacate the death sentences in these cases. Mr. Justice Blackmun
took no part in the consideration or decision of these petitions.
REHEARINGS DENIED

thority of the City of Philadelphia et al.; and
No. 77-5464. Leonard Pryor, petitioner, v. Georgia. Petitions for

eration or decision of these petitions.
