SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-1072. Janice Ching Yee, appellant, v. Alfred Alphonse Yee
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Hawaii. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77–1091. Martin Epstein, appellant, v. Civil Service Commis-
sion et al. Appeal from the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 76-6258. Tyrees Coloza Whitehead, petitioner, v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari are granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further consideration in light of Simpson v. United States, 435
U.S.-(1978).
No. 77-172. Hubert Morelock et al., petitioners, v. NCR Corpora-
tion. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Petition for a writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further consideration in light of Lorillard v. Pons, 434 U.S.
(1978).
No. 77-567. New York State Parole Board and Members of the
New York State Parole Board, etc., petitioners, v. Ernest Coralluzzo.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
260-278-77-54

478
MONDAY, MARCH 6, 1978
Second Circuit. Motion of respondent to dismiss writ granted and
writ of certiorari dismissed as improvidently granted. Mr. Justice
White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist dissent.
No. 77-5742. Kenneth Ray Frakes, petitioner, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Sixth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court
for the Western District of Kentucky with instructions to grant the
government's motion to dismiss the indictment. The Chief Justice, Mr.
Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist dissent.

sioner of Internal Revenue. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit granted.
No. 77–922. Chrysler Corporation, petitoner, v. Harold Brown,
Secretary of Defense, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit granted.

MONDAY, MARCH 6, 1978
OPINIONS
499
No. 76-5729. Mark David Oliphant, petitioner, v. The Suquamish
Indian Tribe et al.; Daniel B. Belgarde, petitioner, v. The Suquamish
Indian Tribe et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment as to Oliphant reversed and
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court; and judgment as to Belgarde
reversed and remanded to the United States District Court for the
Western District of Washington for further proceedings in conform-
ity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Chief
Justice Burger joins. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this case.
No. 76-930. Dixy Lee Ray, Governor of Washington, et al., appel-
lants, v. Atlantic Richfield Company and Seatrain Lines, Incorpo-
rated. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western
District of Washington. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in
part and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
Western District of Washington for further proceedings in conform-
ity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall concurring in part and dissenting in
part with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens concurring in part and dissenting in
part with whom Mr. Justice Powell joins.
No. 76–1662. United States, appellant, v. Board of Commissioners
of Sheffield, Alabama, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Alabama. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Alabama for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell
concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Stevens, with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr.
Justice Rehnquist join.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-688. Long Island Railroad Company, applicant, v. Aber-
deen & Rockfish Railroad Company et al. Application for stay of
judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
in Case No. 77–1054, presented to Mr. Justice Powell and by him re-
ferred to the Court granted, only insofar as the judgment requires ap-
plicant Long Island Railroad Company to keep in a separate trust
fund the proceeds of the interim 12.5 percent terminal surcharge,
pending timely filing of a petition for writ of certiorari. Should a
timely petition for writ of certiorari not be filed or be denied, this

500
MONDAY, MARCH 6, 1978
stay is to terminate automatically. If the petition for writ of certiorari
is granted, this stay is to remain in effect pending judgment of this
Court. In all other respects, application for stay denied. Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this application.
Adjourned until Monday, March 20, 1978, at 10 o'clock.

Powell and by him referred to the Court, granted.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 20, 1978
503
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 77-716. Max Cleland, Administrator of the Veterans Admin-
istration et al., appellants, v. National College of Business. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the District of South
Dakota. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the District of South Dakota for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
Separate statement by Mr. Justice Marshall.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77–794. Ronald R. Silverton, appellant, v. California. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77–987. C. John Forge, Jr., et al., appellants, v. Minnesota.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77-1050. Anna deKam et al., appellants, v. City of Southfield
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Michigan. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77-1130. Jasper Frank Potts, appellant, v. Kentucky. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Kentucky. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77-6055. Edward L. Smith, appellant, v. Louisiana. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77–1056. Sunbeam Television Corporation et al., appellants, v.
Robert L. Shevin, as Attorney General, et al. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice White and
Mr. Justice Blackmun would note probable jurisdiction and set the
case for oral argument.

517
No. 77-5891. Eugene D. Manion, Sr., petitioner, v. Illinois. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois denied.
Mr. Justice Blackmun would grant certiorari.
No. 77–6057. Jerome Bowden, petitioner, v. Georgia. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia denied. Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall, dissenting: Adhering to our
views that the death penalty is in all circumstances cruel and unusual
punishment prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments,
Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231 (1976), we would grant cer-
tiorari and vacate the death sentence in this case.
No. 77-6107. William "Billy" Mitchell, petitioner, v. Joe S. Hop-
per, Warden. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Georgia denied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall, dis-
senting: Adhering to our views that the death penalty is in all cir-
cumstances cruel and unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth
and Fourteenth Amendments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227,
231 (1976), we would grant certiorari and vacate the death sentence
in this case.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITIONS FOR WRITS OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 77-6259. Alvin Seagroves, petitioner, v. Tennessee. Motion for
leave to file petition for writ of habeas corpus denied.
No. 77-1094. Carmine Galante, petitioner, v. Attorney General of
the United States et al. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of
habeas corpus denied. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion.

No. 76-1121. American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., et al., peti-
tioners, v. Writers Guild of America, West, Inc., et al.;
No. 76-1153. Association of Motion Picture and Television Pro-
ducers, Inc., petitioner, v. Writers Guild of America, West, Inc., et
al. and

eis Guild of America, West, Inc., et al. One and one half hours al-
lowed for reargument. Reargued by Mr. Norton J. Come for the peti-
tioner in No. 76–1162, by Mr. Harry J. Keaton for the petitioner in

MONDAY, MARCH 20, 1978
529
No. 76–1153, by Mr. Charles G. Bakaly for the petitioners in No.
76-1121, by Mr. Julius Reich for the respondents, and by Mr. Law-
rence Gold for the AFL-CIO, as amicus curiae, by special leave of
Court.
No. 77–262. Duke Power Company, appellant, v. Carolina Envi-
ronmental Study Group, Inc., et al.; and
No. 77–375. United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission et. al.,
appellants, v. Carolina Environmental Study Group, Inc., et al. One
and one-half hours allowed for oral argument. Argued by Mr. Steve
C. Griffith, Jr., for the appellant in No. 77-262, by Mr. Solicitor Gen-
eral Wade H. McCree, Jr., for the appellants in No. 77-375, and by
Mr. William B. Schultz for the appellees.
No. 76–1193. United States, petitioner, v. Estelle Jacobs aka "Mrs.
Kramer". Reargued by Mr. Andrew L. Frey for the petitioner and
by Mr. Irving P. Seidman for the respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

OPINIONS
No. 76-1151. United States, petitioner, v. Ralph Ceccolini. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec-
ond Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger concurring in judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Mr. Justice
Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 76-1149. John D. Carey et al., petitioners, v. Jarius Piphus,
etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Mr. Justice
Marshall concurs in the result. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 76–761. Claude D. Ballew, petitioner, v. Georgia. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Georgia. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals of Georgia for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the judgment of this Court. Mr.
Justice Blackmun announced the judgment and delivered an opinion
in which Mr. Justice Stevens joined. Concurring statement by Mr.
Justice Stevens. Statement by Mr. Justice White concurring in judg-
ment. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in judgment with
whom Mr. Chief Justice Berger and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
260-278-77-59

532
TUESDAY, MARCH 21, 1978
Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and
Mr. Justice Marshall join.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 77–324. Sidney S. Hicklin et al., appellants, v. Edmund Or-
beck, Commissioner of the Department of Labor of Alaska, et al.
Argued by Mr. Robert H. Wagstaff for the appellants and by Mr.
Ronald W. Lorensen for the appellees.
No. 77-454. Moorman Manufacturing Company, appellant, v.
G. D. Bair, etc. Argued by Mr. Donald K. Barnes for the appellant
and by Mr. Harry M. Griger for the appellee.
No. 77-334. First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Boston
et al., appellants, v. State Tax Commission et al. Argued by Mr.
Chester M. Howe for the appellants and by Mr. S. Stephen Ronsenfeld
for the appellees.
No. 77–178. Willard E. Robertson, petitioner, v. Edward E. Weg-
mann, Executor of the Estate of Clay L. Shaw, et al. Argued by Mr.
Malcolm W. Monroe for the petitioner and by Mr. Edward F. Weg-
mann for the respondents.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

OPINIONS
No. 76–1629. United States, petitioner, v. Anthony Robert Wheeler.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Mr. Justice Brennan
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 76–6942. Ensio Ruben Lakeside, petitioner, v. Oregon. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Oregon. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Stevens with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins with the exception
of the first paragraph and footnote 5. Mr. Justice Brennan took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 76–839. Edmund Foley, appellant, v. William G. Connelie,
etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of New York. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Chief Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in the result. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan
and Mr. Justice Stevens join. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Stevens with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 76-1200. Roger Crist, as Warden of the Montana State Peni-
tentiary, Deer Lodge, Montana, et al., appellants, v. Merrel Cline
and L. R. Bretz. One hour and fifteen minutes allowed for reargument.
Reargued by Mr. Robert S. Keller for the appellants, by Mr. Kenneth
S. Geller for the United States as amicus curiae by special leave of
Court, by Mr. W. William Leaphart for the appellee Merrel Cline
and by Mr. Charles F. Moses for the appellee L. R. Bretz.
No. 76-1836. Coopers & Lybrand, petitioner, v. Cecil Livesay and
Dorothy Livesay, etc., et al.; and
No. 76–1837. Punta Gorda Isles, Inc., petitioner, v. Cecil Livesay
and Dorothy Livesay, etc., et al. Argued by Mr. Thomas C. Walsh for
the petitioners and by Mr. Melvyn I. Weiss for the respondents.
No. 77-560. Jo Ann Evans Gardner, petitioner, v. Westinghouse
Broadcasing Company. Argued by Mr. Robert N. Hackett for the
petitioner and by Mr. Leonard L. Scheinholtz for the respondent.
Adjourned until Monday, March 27, 1978, at 10 o'clock.
✓

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, MARCH 24, 1978
535
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-807. Kenneth Brown et al., applicants, v. Meldrim Thomson,
Jr., Governor of New Hampshire. Application for stay of judgment of
the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit (Misc. No.
78-8029), presented to Mr. Justice Brennan and by him referred to the
Court, granted pending the timely filing and disposition of a petition
for a writ of certiorari in this Court. Should the petition for a writ of
certiorari not be timely filed or denied, this stay is to terminate auto-
matically. In the event the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted,
this stay is to remain in effect pending the issuance of the judgment of
this Court.
The Chief Justice dissenting:
I would not disturb the order of the United States Court of Appeals
for the First Circuit. Moreover, the Attorney General of New Hamp-
shire having this day personally represented to the clerk of this Court
that the Proclamation of March 21, 1978, has been superseded by a new
proclamation dated March 24, 1978, filed today, the application re-
ferred to the Court appears to be moot, and I therefore dissent from
the action of the Court and would reinstate the order of the Court of
Appeals.
Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist
dissenting:
As we would not disturb the order of the Court of Appeals of the
First Circuit, we dissent from the order of this Court.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 27, 1978
537
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-1100. Illinois State Board of Elections, appellant, v. George
E. Sangmeister et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77-6162. Randell Dale Adams, appellant, v. Douglas Mulder
and Henry Wade. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77-5919. Napoleon Richardson and Francisco Chaimowicz, etc.,
appellants, v. W. M. Blumenthal, Secretary of the Treasury, et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Cir-
cuit. The appeal is dismissed for failure to file the notice of appeal
within the time provided by 28 U.S.C. 2101 (a) and Rule 11.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-791. The Fund Of Funds, Limited et al., applicants, v. Ar-
thur Anderson & Co., et al. Application for an extension of time to
file a petition for a writ of certiorari, presented to Mr. Justice Bren-
nan and by him referred to the Court, denied.
No. 54, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. States of
Florida and Texas. Special Master's Accounting of Expense Funds
accepted. It is ordered that the Special Master is discharged.

Company et al.;
No. 76–1133. El Paso Natural Gas Company, petitioner, v. South-

OPINIONS
No. 77–142. United States, petitioner, v. Donald Lavern Culbert.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice Brennan took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 76–1750. Harold D. Stump et al., petitioners, v. Linda Kay
Sparkman and Leo Sparkman. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
White. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr.
Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Powell join. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Powell. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this case.
No. 76-1359. Bankers Trust Company, petitioner, v. Samuel Mal-
lis and Franklyn Kupferman. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Writ of certiorari dis-
missed as improvidently granted. Opinion per curiam announced by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.

OPINIONS
No. 76-1500. Massachusetts, petitioner, v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the First
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Powell concurring in part and
concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins. Mr. Justice Black-
mun took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 76-864. City of Lafayette, Louisiana and City of Plaquemine,
Louisiana, petitioners, v. Louisiana Power & Light Company. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Brennan announced the judg-
ment of the Court and delivered an opinion (Part I), together with
an opinion (Parts II and III), in which Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr.
Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Stevens joined. Concurring opinion
by Mr. Justice Marshall. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger con-
curring in Part I of the plurality opinion and in the judgment. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice
White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join and joined by Mr. Justice
Blackmun in all but Part II-B. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun.
ORAL ARGUMENT

Argued by Mr. Jerome B. Falk, Jr. for the plaintiff and by Mr. John
L. Hill for the defendant.

fornia in and for the City and County of San Francisco (Sharon

MONDAY, APRIL 3, 1978
557
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan. Mr.
Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Jus-
tice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-980. Albert A. Lewis, etc., appellant, v. James L. Cowen et
al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern.
District of Pennsylvania. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Brennan
and Mr. Justice Powell would note probable jurisdiction and set the
case for oral argument.
No. 77–1026. Janene Riley, etc., appellant, v. Ohio et al. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Franklin County. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77–85. J. L. Smalling, Superintendent of Unified School Dis-
trict No. 480, Seward County, Kansas, et al., petitioners, v. Lila Epper-
son et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light
of Carey v. Piphus, 435 U.S.- (1978).
-

558
MONDAY, APRIL 3, 1978
No. D-132. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gene Ira Esser. It is
ordered that Gene Ira Esser of New York, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-133. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gene Loy Chu. It is
ordered that Gene Loy Chu of New York, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 77–529. Wes Wise, Mayor of the City of Dallas, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Albert L. Lipscomb et al. Motion of Solicitor General for
leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, granted and
fifteen minutes allotted for that purpose provided that the brief of the
United States is filed on or before April 10, 1978. If the brief is timely
filed, appellants allotted an additional fifteen minutes for oral
argument.
No. 77-888. Joseph Vitek, etc., et al., appellants, v. Charles Miller
et al. Motion of appellee Larry D. Jones for leave to proceed further
herein in forma pauperis granted. Motion for appointment of coun-
sel granted and it is ordered that Thomas A. Wurtz, Esquire, of Lin-
coln, Nebraska, is appointed to serve as counsel for appellee Larry D.
Jones in this case.
No. 77-1207. Barbara B. Blum, Acting Commissioner, New York
State Department of Social Services, et. al., petitioners. v. Martin
Toomey et al. Solicitor General invited to file a brief in this case ex-
pressing the views of the United States.
No. 77-6111. James Lee Brown, petitioner, v. United States. Appli
cation for stay, presented to Mr. Justice Stevens and by him referred
to the Court, denied.
No. 77-6354. Mary C. Northern, appellant. v. Tennessee Depart-
ment of Human Services. Motion to expedite denied.

et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of

Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Colorado
denied.
No. 77-1132. New Mexico, ex rel. Environmental Improvement
Agency, petitioner, v. Albuquerque Publishing Company. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of New Mexico denied it
appearing that the judgment below rests upon adequate state
grounds.
No. 77-1175. Illinois, petitioner, v. Maurice Pendleton. Motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, First Dis-
trict. denied it appearing that the judgment below rests upon ade-
quate state grounds.
No. 77-5874. Deborah Lynn Little, petitioner, v. Arkansas. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arkansas denied.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice
Brennan joins.

No. 76–419. Vermont Yankee Nuclear Power Corporation, peti-
tioner, v. Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc., et al.; and
No. 76–528. Consumers Power Company, petitioner, v. Nelson
Aeschliman et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgments reversed
and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist. Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Powell took no part
in the consideration or decision of these cases.
No. 76-1184. E. I. Malone, Commissioner of Labor and Industry for
Minnesota, appellant, v. White Motor Corporation and White Farm
Equipment Company. Appeal from the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger
joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Chief
Justice Burger joins. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Blackmun
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

MONDAY, APRIL 3, 1978
579
No. 76–5856. Winston M. Holloway et al., petitioners, v. Arkansas.
On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arkansas. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Arkansas for
further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Powell with whom Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist join.
Adjourned until Monday, April 17, 1978, at 10 o'clock.
Х

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 17, 1978
581
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice.
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 77-5898. Maurice Proctor, petitioner, v. Warden, Maryland
Penitentiary. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States.
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-16. United States, appellant, v. Georgia Department of
Transportation. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Georgia. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia
for further consideration in light of Massachusetts v. United States,
435 U.S. (1978).
No. 77-971. North Carolina, ex rel. Sarah T. Morrow, et al., appel-
lants, v. Joseph A. Califano, Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and
Welfare, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of North Carolina. Motion of Pacific Legal Foun-
dation for leave to file à brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of
Association of American Physicians and Surgeons, Inc. for leave to
file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Judgment affirmed.
No. 77-981. M.R.T.S., Inc., dba Classic Cat Theater, appellant, v.
Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control of the State of California,
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Appel-
late District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 77-982. Lettie Linda Tasselli et al., appellants, v. Department
of Alcoholic Beverage Control of the State of California, et al. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
260-278-77—67

582
MONDAY, APRIL 17, 1978
No. 77–1179. Lawrence J. Stockler, etc., appellant, v. Michigan et
al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Michigan. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77–1211. Linda Fay Regenold, appellant, v. Baby Fold, Inc.,
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77-1188. Minnie Bryan Breza, appellant, v. City of Trimont.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77–6228. Stanwood A. Demers, appellant, v. Rhode Island et
al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the First Cir-
cuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari denied.
No. 77–6231. Betty O. Muka, appellant, v. DeForrest Heffron, as
President of the Ithaca Teachers Association, et al. Appeal from the
Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77-6244. Edward O. Marschall et ux., appellants, v. Joel K.
Kristensen et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Washington,
Division 2. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77-6313. Maxine M. Jenkins, appellant, v. District of Colum-
bia. Appeal from the District of Columbia Court of Appeals. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
No. 77-6149. John M. Harper, appellant, v. Charles T. Duffey.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Massachusetts. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 76–548. Baltimore Gas and Electric Co., et al., petitioners, v.
Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc., et al. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further con-
sideration in light of Vermont Yankee Nuclear Power Corp. v. Nat-
ural Resources Defense Council, 435 U.S. - (1978). Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

MONDAY, APRIL 17, 1978
583
No. 76–745. Long Island Lighting Company, petitioner, v. The
Lloyd Harbor Study Group, Inc. On petition for writ to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case re-
manded to Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of Ver-
mont Yankee Nuclear Power Corp. v. Natural Resources Defense
Council, 435 U.S. (1978). Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 77-947. Donald E. Bordenkircher, Superintendent, Kentucky
State Penitentiary, petitioner, v. John Randolph Gaston. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further con-
sideration in light of Bordenkircher v. Hayes, 434 U.S. (1978).
Mr. Justice Marshall dissents.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-817. Joel Weinstein, applicant, v. Florida. Application for
stay, presented to Mr. Justice Marshall and by him referred to the
Court, denied.
No. A–863. Mickey Edwards et al., applicants, v. James Earl Car-
ter, President of the United States. Application for an injunction, pre-
sented to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court, denied.
No. D-130. In the Matter of Disbarment of Royal E. Spurlark, Jr.
It having been reported to the Court that Royal E. Spurlark, Jr. has
been reinstated on the roll of attorneys admitted to practice in the
State of Illinois, it is ordered that the order of this Court entered
January 9, 1978, suspending Royal E. Spurlark, Jr. from further
practice of law in this Court is vacated and that the rule to show.
cause issued January 9, 1978, is discharged.

Hill, Jr., et al. Motion of Pacific Legal Foundation for leave to par-
ticipate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, denied.

v. Charlestone Stone Products Co., Inc. Motion of J. Alan Steele for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.

respondent for divided argument granted.

Inc., et al., for leave to participate in oral argument, as amici curiae,
denied.

No. 76–944. Richard Nixon, petitioner, v. Warner Communications,

for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the United States District Court for the District of Co-
lumbia with directions that an order be entered denying respondents'
application with prejudice. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Opinion
by Mr. Justice White dissenting in part with whom Mr. Justice Bren-
nan joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.

Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court.
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting state-
ment by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.

OPINIONS
No. 77-154. Wilson H. Elkins, President, University of Maryland,
petitioner, v. Juan Carlos Moreno et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Question to be
certified to the Court of Appeals of Maryland pursuant to Md. Code
Ann., Courts & Jud. Proceedings, § 12-601 (1974): Are persons resid-
ing in Maryland who hold or are named in a visa under 8 U.S.C. § 1101
(a) (15) (G) (iv) (1976 ed.), or who are financially dependent upon a
person holding or named in such a visa, incapable as a matter of State
law of becoming domiciliaries of Maryland? Opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr.
Chief Justice Burger joins.
No. 76–1427. Paul A. McDaniel, appellant, v. Selma Cash Paty
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Tennessee, Eastern Division.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Ten-
nessee, Eastern Division, for further proceedings not inconsistent with
the judgment of this Court. Mr. Chief Justice Burger announced the
judgment of this Court and delivered an opinion in which Mr. Justice
Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens joined. Opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in the judgment with whom
Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart concurring
in the judgment. Opinion by Mr. Justice White concurring in the judg-
ment. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.
ORAL AGREEMENT
No. 77-528. Federal Communications Commission, petitioner, v.
Pacifica Foundation. Argument continued by Mr. Louis F. Claiborne

WEDNESDAY, APRIL 19, 1978

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITIONS
No. 76–1738. William M. Sewell, appellant, v. Georgia. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Stewart.
No. 77-790. Warren Teal, appellant, v. Georgia. Appeal from the
Court of Appeals of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Bren-
nan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart.
No. 77–915. Ernest H. Robinson, appellant, v. Georgia. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Georgia. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals of Georgia for further consideration
in light of Ballew v. Georgia, 435 U.S.
(1978). Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall
joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart.
No. 77-1220. John L.Schroeder, appellant, v. Municipal Court of
the Los Cerritos Judicial District (California, real party in interest).
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 77–1229. Gary George Huffman, etc., appellant v. Kentucky
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Kentucky. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77-6365. John H. Gill, appellant, v. Kathleen M. Gill et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Cir-
cuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of cer-
tiorari, certiorari denied.
260-278-77-71

612
MONDAY, APRIL 24, 1978
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-440. Pleasure Driveway and Park District of Peoria, Illi-
nois, et al., petitioners v. William Kurek et al. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated
and cases remanded to Court of Appeals for further consideration in
light of City of Lafayette v. Louisiana Power and Light Co., 435
U.S.
(1978). Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this case.
-
No. 77–734. City of Impact, et al., petitioners, v. Edgar E. Whit-
worth, etc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for a writ of certiorari
granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further consideration in light of City of Lafayette v. Louisiana
Power and Light Co., 435 U.S. — (1978).
-
No. 77-826. Fairfax Hospital Association, et al., petitioners, v.
City of Fairfax, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Petition for a writ
of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of City of Lafay-
ette v. Louisiana Power and Light Co., 435 U.S. — (1978).
-
No. 77–835. University of Texas System et al., petitioners, v. Said
A. Assaf. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
District Court for the Southern District of Texas with directions to
dismiss the case as moot. Board of Regents of the University of Texas
System v. New Left Education Project, 414 U.S. 807 (1973).

for the District of Columbia Circuit.

suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,

Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied.
No. 77-6324. Richard Aldon Burrell, petitioner, v. W. J. Estelle,
Jr., Director, Texas Department of Corrections. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
denied.
No. 77-6329. Homer Lee Sherley, Jr., petitioner, v. Kentucky.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky
denied.
No. 77–6417. Raymond L. Watkins, etc., petitioner, v. Lou Bach-
rodt Chevrolet, Inc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Appellate
Court of Illinois, Second District, denied.
No. 77-6436. Eddie Roy Gay, petitioner, v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 77–6446. Louis William Roach, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit denied.

618
MONDAY, APRIL 24, 1978
No. 77–6449. Arthur W. Clyburn, Jr., petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the District of Columbia Court of
Appeals denied.
No. 77-6452. Frank Black Horse, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit denied.
No. 77–6453. Lorenzo Hernandez and Luis Hernandez, petitioners,
v. United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 77–6461. Frank Sacco, petitioner, v. United States. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit denied.
No. 77-6491. Robert Jackson, petitioner, v. Virginia. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Virginia denied.
No. 77–1089. Patricia Campbell Hearst, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan would grant
certiorari limited to questions VII and VIII presented by the petition.
No. 77–1308. National Broadcasting Company, Inc., et al., peti-
tioners, v. Olivia Niemi, etc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate District, denied. Mr.
Justice Brennan would grant certiorari.
No. 77–1329. Ohio, petitioner, v. Danie Lee Teter. Motion of re-
spondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Summit
County, denied.
No. 77–1385. Gary Allen May, petitioner, v. Indiana. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Indiana denied. Mr.
Justice Stewart would grant certiorari.
No. 77-5953. Thomas Riley, petitioner, v. Illinois. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, denied.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice
Brennan joins.
No. 77–6016. Lynell Franklin et al., petitioners, v. Pleasant C.
Shields et al. Motion of Public Defender of Wisconsin for leave to
file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied.
Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall
would grant certiorari.
No. 77-6288. Richard Henry Gibson, petitioner, v. Florida. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied. Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall, dissenting: Adhering to

MONDAY, APRIL 24, 1978
619
our views that the death penalty is in all circumstances cruel and
unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth
Amendments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231 (1976), we
would grant certiorari and vacate the death sentence in this case.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITIONS FOR WRITS OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 77–6462. Elmer Begley, Jr., petitioner, v. James Carter, etc.,
et al., and
No. 77-6479. Robert Allen Ricks, petitioner, v. George Collins,
Warden. Motions for leave to file petitions for writs of habeas corpus
denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITIONS FOR WRITS OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 77-1200. American Association of Councils of Medical Staffs
of Private Hospitals, Inc., petitioner, v. Judges of the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion for leave to file peti-
tion for writ of mandamus denied.
No. 77–1131. In the Matter of the Vendo Company, petitioner. On
February 10, 1978, petitioner filed for leave to file a petition for writ
of mandamus and further prayed that a writ of mandamus issue to
the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois
directing the District Court to dissolve the preliminary injunction in
Lektro-Vend Corp. v. Vendo Co., No. 65-C-1755. In Vendo Co. v.
Lektro-Vend Corp., 433 U.S. 623 (1977), this Court had held that
the preliminary injunction violated the Anti-Injunction Act, 28
U.S.C. § 2283. The Court has now been advised of an order entered on
April 6, 1978, dissolving the injunction in accordance with the judg-
ment of this Court. Petitioner's motion is therefore dismissed as moot.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 77–863. Mark Frederick Buthorn, Jr., petitioner, v. United
States; and
No. 77-1028. Insurance Company of North America, petitioner,
v. Robert Lee Mosley et al. Petitions for rehearing denied.
ORDER
It is ordered that the call of the calendar, except for special assign-
ments, be suspended for the term upon the conclusion of the argu-
ments in the cases listed for hearing this week.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, May 1, 1978, until
Monday, May 15, 1978.

OPINIONS
No. 76–1767. National Society of Professional Engineers, peti-
tioner, v. United States. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun concurring in part and concurring in judgment with whom
Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger
concurring in part and dissenting in part. Mr. Justice Brennan took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 76–1810. City of Los Angeles, Department of Water and
Power, et al., petitioners, v. Marie Manhart et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Stevens. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in
part and concurring in judgment. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom Mr. Jus-
tice Rehnquist joins. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall concurring in
part and dissenting in part. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 1, 1978
631
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief
Justice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77–1061. Maxwell Darks, appellant, v. Transok Pipe Line
Company. Appeal from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77-1250. International Tracers of America, appellant, v. Es-
tate of Eric Hard et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Washing-
ton. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77–1285. Township of Midland et al., appellants, v. Michigan
State Boundary Commission et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Michigan. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 77–6361. Eli Raitport, appellant, v. Acro-Matic, Inc. Appeal
from the Superior Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77-1176. Nabisco, Inc., et al., appellants, v. Bernard Korzen
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. Motion of North-
western University for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77–1287. Jack Lee Fisher, appellant, v. Ohio. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Ohio. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77-6289. Joseph Duane Ward, appellant, v. Utah. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Utah. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the paper whereon the appeal was taken as
a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 76–1560. United States, petitioner, v. United States Gypsum
Company et al. Motion of respondents Colon Brown and J. P. Nicely
for leave to file supplemental brief, after argument granted. Mr. Jus-
tice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.

632
MONDAY, MAY 1, 1978
No. 77–1234. International Association of Machinists & Aerospace
Workers, AFL-CIO, petitioners, v. Compagnie Nationale Air France.
The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing
the views of the United States.
No. 77-1471. Mickey Edwards et al., petitioners, v. James Earl
Carter, President of the United States. Motion of petitioners to expe-
dite consideration of the petition for writ of certiorari denied.
Application for an injunction, presented to the Chief Justice and by
him referred to the Court, denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 77-1301. Gannett Co., Inc., petitioner, v. Daniel A. DePas-
quale, etc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Ap-
peals of New York granted.
No. 77-1305. Parklane Hosiery Company, Inc., et al., petitioners,
v. Leo M. Shore. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit granted.
No. 77–6067. Billy Duren, petitioner, v. Missouri. Motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Missouri granted.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 77-755. Rocky Mountain Motor Tariff Bureau, Inc., and Bulk
Carrier Conference, Inc., petitioners v. United States and Interstate
Commerce Commission. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied.
No. 77-1008. Sioux City and New Orleans Barge Lines, Inc., peti-
tioner, v. Helena Marine Service. Inc.. etc. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit
denied.

No. 77–6456. Eduardo Johnny Montoya-Guerrero, petitioner, v.
United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States

Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit denied.
No. 77-6490. Carlos Andres Ortiz Olivera, petitioner, v. United
States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of

No. 77–6495. Richard G. Warme, petitioner, v. United States. Pe-

No. 77-784. Maryland, petitioner, v. Victor Dennis Marzullo. Mo-
tion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
White with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins.
No. 77–943. Illinois, petitioner, v. Robert L. Gray. Motion of re-
spondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois denied it appearing
that the judgment of the Illinois Supreme Court rests on an adequate
state ground. Separate statement by Mr. Justice Stevens. Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall would deny the petition without
explanation.
No. 77–1262. Louis Beck, petitioner, v. Morrison Pump Co., Inc.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 77–1266. Ernest N. Morial et al., petitioners, v. Judiciary Com-
mission of the State of Louisiana et al. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
Mr. Justice White would grant certiorari.

MONDAY, MAY 1, 1978
637
No. 77-1277. Missouri State Highway Commission, petitioner, v.
Rachel J. Meyer. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied.
No. 77–6025. David S. Huffman, petitioner, v. Florida. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
Separate opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 77–6359. Willie X. Ross, petitioner, v. Joe S. Hopper, Warden.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia denied.
Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall, dissenting: Adhering
to our views that the death penalty is in all circumstances cruel and
unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amend-
ments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231 (1976), we would grant
certiorari and vacate the death sentence in this case.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITIONS FOR WRITS OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 77-6278. Henry W. Knight, petitioner, v. United States Dis-
trict Court for the District of Massachusetts:
No. 77-6352. Robert W. Townsley, petitioner, v. Alan A. Lindsay,
Alameda County Superior Court, et al.; and
No. 77–6358. William Q. Siddle, petitioner, v. United States Dis-
trict Court for the Southern District of Ohio et al. Motions for leave
to file petitions for writs of mandamus denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 76-1719. Washington Medical Center, Inc., et al., petitioners,
v. United States;
No. 77-953. Buffalo River Conservation & Recreation Council et al.,
petitioners, v. National Park Service et al.;
No. 77-1056. Sunbeam Television Corporation et al., appellants, v.
Robert L. Shevin, as Attorney General et al.;
No. 77–5733. William R. Morgan, Jr., petitioner, v. United States;
and
No. 77-5965. Eddie David Cox, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tions for rehearing denied.

OPINIONS
No. 76–39. Memphis Light, Gas and Water Division, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Willie S. Craft et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Stevens with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist join.
No. 75–1892. United States, petitioner, v. Jeffrey R. MacDonald.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Mr. Justice Bren-
nan took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 76-1450. Landmark Communications, Inc., appellant, v. Vir-
ginia. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Virginia for fur-
ther proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart
concurring in the judgment. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 76–1193. United States, petitioner, v. Estelle Jacobs aka "“Mrs.
Kramer". On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. Writ of certiorari dismissed as improvidently
granted. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Adjourned until Monday, May 15, 1978, at 10 o'clock.
Х

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 15, 1978
647
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 76–1616. County of Los Angeles et al., appellants, v. Jose Cha-
vez-Salido et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Central District of California. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the United States District Court for the Central District
of California for further consideration in light of Foley v. Connelie,
435 U.S.
(1978).
No. 77-950. Collection Consultants, Inc., and Stella Thornton, ap-
pellants, v. Texas. Appeal from the Court of Criminal Appeals of
Texas. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 77–6409. William E. Conrad, appellant, v. Commerce Bank
of Kansas City. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Missouri, St.
Louis District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial fed-
eral question.
No. 77-6447. Harold Smith, appellant, v. Illinois. Appeal from
the Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-726. Allan G. Kaplan, applicant, v. New Jersey. Applica-
tion for stay, presented to Mr. Justice Blackmun, and by him referred
to the Court, denied.
No. A-930. City of Mobile, Alabama, et al., applicants, v. Wiley L.
Bolden, et al. Application for recall and stay of mandate presented to
Mr. Justice Powell, and by him referred to the Court, denied. Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart and Mr. Justice Rehnquist would grant application.
No. 77-1373. Maine Central Railroad Company, appellant, v. Ray-
mond L. Halpern et al. Solicitor General invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States.

MONDAY, MAY 15, 1978
No. 77-1538. Alan Herbert Abrahams, aka James A. Carr, peti-
tioner, v. United States. Application for bail, presented to Mr. Justice
Powell and by him referred to the Court, denied.
No. 77–6639. Willis W. Chapman, petitioner, v. Federal National
Mortgage Association. Application for stay, presented to the Chief
Justice and by him referred to the Court, denied.

noted.

No. 77-6597. Melvin Thomas Wilcox, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 77-6608. James Wimbley, petitioner, v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 77–6609. Melvin Shane, petitioner, v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit denied.
No. 77-6613. Robert Lee Baer, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit denied.
No. 77-6620. John Michael Williams, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit denied.
No. 77-1003. James V. Napoli, Sr., and James Napoli, Jr., peti-
tioners, v. United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Stewart would grant certiorari.
No. 77–1066. Eugene Enslin, petitioner, v. J. W. Bean, Superin-
tendent, New Hanover County Prison Unit, North Carolina Depart-
ment of Correction. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan
and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant certiorari.
No. 77-1201. Zeigler Coal Company, petitioner, v. Local Union No.
1870, United Mine Workers of America, et al. Motion of Bituminous
Coal Operators' Association, Inc. for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied.
No. 77-1275. Martin B. Glauser Dodge Co., petitioner, v. Chrysler
Corporation et al. Motion of Independent Dealers Committee Dedi-
cated to Action for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit denied.

MONDAY, MAY 15, 1978
657
No. 77–1279. Malcolm K. Fleschner et al., petitioners, v. Robert
Abrahamson et ux. Motion of Investment Counsel Association of
America, Inc. for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Powell
would grant certiorari.
No. 77–1284. Russel James Gaudet, petitioner, v. Exxon Corpora-
tion; and
No. 77–1328. Ruven J. St. Pierre, petitioner, v. Exxon Corpora-
tion et al. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of these petitions.
No. 77–1345. Telephone Users Association, Inc., petitioner, v. Pub-
lic Service Commission of the District of Columbia et al. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the District of Columbia Court of Appeals denied.
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
petition.
No. 77–1341. Leon Vincent, Superintendent of Green Haven Cor-
rectional Facility, petitioner, v. Efrain Santiago. Motion of respond-
ent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari tō the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit denied.
No. 77–1346. Lewis S. Taylor, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Luis A.
Rodriguez, etc. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit denied.
No. 77–1421. Lahman Manufacturing Company, Inc., et al., peti-
tioners, v. Farmhand, Inc. Motion to defer consideration of petition
and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eighth Circuit denied.
No. 77–6095. Edward Sawyer, petitioner, v. Florida. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third
District, denied. Mr. Justice Brennan would grant certiorari.
No. 77-6202. Jerry St. John, petitioner, v. W. J. Estelle, Jr., Di-
rector, Texas Department of Corrections. Petition for writ of certi-
orari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun would grant certiorari.
No. 77-6378. Joseph Thomas, petitioner, v. Georgia. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia denied. Mr. Jus-
tice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall, dissenting: Adhering to our
views that the death penalty is in all circumstances cruel and unusual
punishment prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments,
Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231 (1976), we would grant certi-
orari and vacate the death sentence in this case.

658
MONDAY, MAY 15, 1978
No. 77-6424. Charles Thomas Corn, petitioner, v. Georgia. Péti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia denied.
Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall, dissenting: Adhering
to our views that the death penalty is in all circumstances cruel and
unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amend-
ments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231 (1976), we would
grant certiorari and vacate the death sentence in this case.
No. 77–6542. Eddie Earl Hopson and Durand Cephas, petitioners,
v. United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Stevens
took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF PROHIBITION DENIED
No. 77–1438. John Walsh, petitioner, v. H. Kenneth Wangelin,
United States District Judge. Motion for leave to file petition for
writ of prohibition denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITIONS FOR WRITS OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 77–6362. Clovis Carl Green, Jr., petitioner, v. Elmo B. Hunter,
Judge, United States District Court for the Western District of Mis-
souri; and
No. 77–6379. Clovis Carl Green, Jr., petitioner, v. United States
District Court for the Western District of Missouri. Motions for leave
to file petitions for writs of mandamus denied.

OPINIONS
No. 76-750. Sears, Roebuck and Co., petitioner, v. San Diego
County District Council of Carpenters. On writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of California. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of California for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Stevens. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Marshall join.

MONDAY, MAY 15, 1978
673
No. 76–1607. Securities and Exchange Commission, petitioner, v.
Samuel H. Sloan. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in
judgment with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun concurring in judgment.
No. 76–6767. Frank R. Scott, etc. and Bernis L. Thurmon, etc.,
petitioners, v. United States. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins.
No. 77–25. Flagg Brothers, Inc., etc., et al., petitioners, v. Shirley
Herriott Brooks et al.;
No. 77-37. Louis J. Leftkowitz, Attorney General of New York,
petitioner, v. Shirley Herriott Brooks et al.; and
No. 77-42. American Warehousemen's Association and the Inter-
national Association of Refrigerated Warehouses, Inc., petitioners, v.
Shirley Herriott Brooks et al. On writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed
and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with whom Mr. Justice White and
Mr. Justice Marshall join. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 76-682. Santa Clara Pueblo et al., petitioners, v. Julia Mar-
tinez et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice
Rehnquist join Parts I, II, IV, and V of this opinion. Dissenting opin-
ion by Mr. Justice White. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 77–293. Ezra Kulko, appellant, v. Superior Court of Califor-
nia in and for the City and County of San Francisco (Sharon Kulko
Horn, real party in interest). Appeal from the Supreme Court of
California. Appeal dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating papers
whereon appeal was taken a petition for certiorari, certiorari granted,
judgment reversed and case remanded to Supreme Court of Cali-
fornia for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice
Powell join.

674
MONDAY, MAY 15, 1978
No. 5, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
California. On motion of State of California for entry of third sup-
plemental decree. Motion of State of California for entry of third sup-
plemental decree granted. Parties requested to submit an appropriate
decree within 90 days. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger
and Mr. Justice Blackmun join. Mr. Justice Marshall took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
Adjourned until Monday, May 22, 1978, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 22, 1978
675
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice
White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Pow-
ell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
Mr. Justice Brennan said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by Mr. Justice
Brennan, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77–1371. James T. Conway, appellant, v. Wisconsin. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77-1380. James Hepperle, appellant, v. Roy Ricks et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Cir-
cuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-891. E. Jan Roberts, applicant, v. United States. Applica-
tion for an extension of time in which to file a petition for writ of cer-
tiorari, presented to Mr. Justice Marshall and by him referred to the
Court, granted and time to file such petition extended to and includ-
ing May 30, 1978.
No. A-954. American Telephone and Telegraph Company, appli-
cant, v. MCI Telecommunications Corporation et al.; and
No. A-966. United States Independent Telephone Association,
applicant, v. MCI Telecommunications Corporation et al. Applica-
tions for stay of April 14, 1978, order of the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, Case No. 75–1635, pre-
sented to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court, denied.
No. 73, Original. State of California, plaintiff, v. State of Nevada.
Motion of California State Assemblyman Mike Cullen for leave to file
a brief, as amicus curiae; motion of Nevada for leave to file amended
answer setting forth counterclaim; and motion of California for leave
to file amended complaint referred to the Special Master.
No. 77-5992. Frank O'Neal Addington, appellant, v. Texas. Motion
of appellant for appointment of counsel granted and it is ordered that
Martha L. Boston, of Austin, Texas, is appointed to serve as counsel
for appellant in this case.

MONDAY, MAY 22, 1978
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED

No. 77–1134. Montana et al., appellants, v. United States. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the District of Montana.
In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 77-1387. Federal Open Market Committee of the Federal
Reserve System, petitioner, v. David R. Merrill. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit granted.
No. 77-1258. Minnesota, petitioner, v. First of Omaha Service
Corporation et al.; and
No. 77–1265. Marquette National Bank of Minneapolis, petitioner,
v. First of Omaha Service Corporation et al. Petitions for writs of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Minnesota granted. Cases con-
solidated and a total of one hour allotted for oral argument. In addi-
tion to the questions presented by the petitions, parties directed to
brief and argue the jurisdictional issue as to whether petitions were
timely filed.

No. 77–6498. James McBride, petitioner, v. Delta Air Lines, Inc.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit denied.
No. 77-6499. Alfred Menard, petitioner, v. Nebraska. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Nebraska denied.
No. 77-6500. James Willie Cleveland, petitioner, v. Maryland.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Special Appeals of Mary-
land denied.
No. 77–6504. Monty Lee Eddings, petitioner, v. Oklahoma. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Okla-
homa denied.
No. 77–6505. McArthur Watson, petitioner, v. New Jersey. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of New Jersey denied.
No. 77-6507. Cheryl Todd, petitioner, v. Georgia. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Georgia denied.
No. 77–6509. Robert Lesley Goode, Jr., petitioner, v. E. P. Perini,
Superintendent, Marion Correctional Institution. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit
denied.
No. 77–6512. Ruth Anna Kickasola, petitioner, v. Jim Wallace Oil
Company et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals
of Georgia denied.
No. 77-6515. James Roy Hill, petitioner. v. Donald Wyrick,
Warden. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied.
No. 77-6523. Abdur-Rahim Dib Dudar, petitioner, v. United
States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied.
No. 77–6524. Juanita K. Snyder, petitioner v. Dan E. Snyder et al.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit denied.

of Internal Revenue. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.

for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Kentucky denied.

MONDAY, MAY 22, 1978
681
No. 77–6606. Reginald Edison Wright, petitioner, v. W. J. Es-
telle, Jr., Director, Texas Department of Corrections. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas denied.
No. 77-6633. William J. Pierce, petitioner, v. Indiana et al. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit denied.
No. 77–6672. Evelyn Frist, petitioner, v. Wesley M. Walker, et al.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit denied.
No. 77–689. Indiana & Michigan Electric Company, petitioner, v.
City of Mishawaka, Indiana, et al. Motion of Edison Electric Institute
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Cir-
cuit denied.
No. 77–1015. Ronald Prate et al., petitioners, v. Elisha Freedman,
etc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice White would
grant certiorari.
No. 77–1106. James T. O'Brien, petitioner, v. Pennsylvania. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania,
Eastern District, denied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice White
would grant certiorari.
No. 77-1408. Dando Enterprises, Ltd., petitioner, v. Joseph H.
Pritchett et al. Motion of respondent for damages denied. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit denied.
No. 77-6325. Blair Watson, petitioner, v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Powell
would grant certiorari.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 77–6657. William E. Conrad, petitioner, v. First State Bank &
Trust Co. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of habeas corpus
denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 77–959. Isaac Newton Hulver, petitioner, v. United States;
No. 77-5874. Deborah Lynn Little, petitioner, v. Arkansas;
No. 77–5995. Gino Reda, petitioner, v. United States;
No. 77-6079. Allen Blair Smith, petitioner, v. United States;
No. 77-6276. Jack Dempsey Phillips, petitioner, v. J. Robert Olian,
etc., et al.; and
No. 77–6462. Elmer Begley, Jr., petitioner, v. James Carter, etc.,
et al. Petitions for rehearing denied.

RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Tuesday, May 23, 1978, until Tues-
day, May 30, 1978.
