OPINIONS
No. 76–1800. United States, petitioner, v. Onofre J. Sotelo and
Naomi Sotelo. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Stevens join.
No. 76–1835. Ike Slodov, petitioner, v. United States. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Concurring opinion by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with
whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Blackman join.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.
Х
1
'

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MAY 23, 1978
699
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice
White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice.
Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
OPINIONS
No. 76-1150. Lester Baldwin et al., appellants, v. Fish and Game
Commission of Montana et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the District of Montana. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr.
Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 76–1143. Ray Marshall, Secretary of Labor, et al., appellants, v.
Barlow's, Inc. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Idaho. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice White.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with whom Mr. Justice
Blackmun and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Mr. Justice Brennan took
no part in the consideration or decision of the case.
No. 76–1596. United States, petitioner, v. John Mauro and John
Fusco; and
No. 77-52. United States, petitioner, v. Richard Thompson Ford,
On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Judgment in No. 76–1596 reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Judgment in No. 77-52 affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Justice White. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist concurring
in judgment in No. 76-1596 and dissenting in No. 77-52 with whom
Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins.
No. 77-39. William Pinkus, dba "Rosslyn News Company" and
"Kamera", petitioner, v. United States. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in the judgment with
whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.
260-278-77-79

700
TUESDAY, MAY 23, 1978
No. 77–888. Joseph Vitek, etc., et al., appellants, v. Charles Miller
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of Nebraska. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the District of Nebraska for consideration
of the question of mootness. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr.
Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
Adjourned until Tuesday, May 30, 1978, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, MAY 25, 1978
701
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-997. Ronald Douthit, applicant, v. Georgia. Application for
stay of execution of the death sentence in this case, presented to Mr.
Justice Powell and by him referred to the Court, denied. Mr. Justice.
Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant stay.
Х
260-278-77---80

i

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MAY 30, 1978
703
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice
White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice
Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
Mr. Justice Brennan said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by Mr. Justice.
Brennan, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 77-1237. General Atomic Company, petitioner, v. Edwin L.
Felter, District Judge, etc., et al. On motion for leave to file petition
for writ of mandamus. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of
mandamus granted. Assuming as we do that the Santa Fe Court will
now conform to our previous judgment by promptly vacating or modi-
fying its order of December 16, 1977, to the extent that it places any
restriction whatsoever upon GAC's exercise of its right to litigate
arbitration claims in federal forums, we do not at present issue a
formal writ of mandamus. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-1150. Concerned Citzens of Southern Ohio, Inc., et al.,
appellants, v. The Pine Creek Conservancy District et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio.
Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice White and Mr.
Justice Marshall would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument.
No. 77-5063. Robert H. Scott and Lulu Mae Scott, appellants, v.
Federal National Mortgage Association, etc. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Missouri. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration
or decision of this appeal.
No. 77-6217. Edward Ray Stacy, etc., appellant, v. Florida. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77-6354. Mary C. Northern, appellant, v. Tennessee, De-
partment of Human Services. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Tennessee, Middle Division. The appeal is dismissed as moot.
260-278-77-81

704
TUESDAY, MAY 30, 1978
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77–371. Reece Shirley et al., petitioners, v. Retail Store Em-
ployees Union, etc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Su-
preme Court of Kansas. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Kansas for
further consideration in light of Sears, Roebuck & Co. v. San Diego
County District Council of Carpenters, 436 U.S. — (1978).
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
-
No. A-967. Der-Rong Chour, applicant, v. Benedict J. Ferro, etc.,
et al. Application for stay of deportation, presented to Mr. Justice
Brennan and by him referred to the Court, denied. The Chief Justice,
Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Powell would reject application
since it was not signed by counsel.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 77-1119. William Herbert Orr, appellant, v. Lillian M. Orr.
Appeal from Supreme Court of Alabama. In this case probable juris-
diction noted.

No. 77-6659. George W. Supplee, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit denied.
No. 77-6674. Sylvester Smith, petitioner, v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit denied.
No. 77–6681. Theodore W. Bettker, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit denied.
No. 77-6687. Floyd August Davis, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit denied.
No. 77–6688. Daniel E. Snead, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit denied.
No. 76–1523. David B. Swoap, etc., petitioner, v. Marguarita Gar-
cia et al. Motion of respondents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of
California, Second Appellate District, denied. Mr. Justice Stewart
would grant certiorari.
No. 76-1799. Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation, peti-
tioner, v. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 76–1826. Robert R. London, Rufus Jones and Julius Cottman,
petitioners, v. United States;
No. 76-1852. Richard James Genco, petitioner, v. United States;
and
No. 76-6978. John Shade, petitioner, v. United States. Petitions for
writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan would grant certiorari.
No. 76-6637. Chloe V. Daviage, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the District of Columbia Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan would
grant certiorari.
No. 76-6828. Thomas Fury, petitioner, v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan would grant certiorari.

710
TUESDAY, MAY 30, 1978
No. 77–5291. Albert Lee aka Alphonso Lee, petitioner, v. United
States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit denied. Mr. Justice
Brennan would grant certiorari.
No. 77-1077. James D. Graves, et ux., petitioners, v. White Moun-
tain Apache Tribe, etc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court
of Appeals of Arizona, Division One, denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun
would grant certiorari.
No. 77–1226. Bruce Long, petitioner, v. United States. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec-
ond Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with
whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 77-1253. Leslie W. Nimmo et al., petitioners, v. Charles S.
Grainger et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Powell
would grant certiorari.
No. 77–1330. Roy Isakson et al., petitioners, v. United States et al.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 77-1339. Michael Robinson, petitioner, v. City of Birmingham.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of
Alabama denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with
whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 77-1418. Consolidated Motor Inns., petitioner, v. Alias Enter-
prises, Ltd. Motion of BVA Credit Corporation for leave to file a
brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
No. 77-1490. Learie Leo Alford, petitioner, v. Florida. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan
joins.
No. 77-1510. Surety Title Insurance Agency, Inc., petitioner, v.
Virginia State Bar. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice White
would grant certiorari.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No 77-6727. Robert Earl Green, Sr., petitioner, v. Blair Lee, III,
Governor of Maryland, et al. Motion for leave to file petition for
writ of habeas corpus denied.

OPINIONS
McCree, Jr.
Wade H.
McCree, Jr.
Solicitor General
Wade H.
McCree, Jr.
No. 77-56. In the matter of Edna Smith Primus, appellant. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of South Carolina. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of South Carolina for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Powell. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall concurring in part and concurring
in the judgment in this case and in No. 76-1650, post. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 76-1650. Albert Ohralik, appellant, v. Ohio State Bar Asso-
ciation. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Ohio. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall
concurring in part and concurring in the judgment in this case and
in No. 77-56, ante. Statement by Mr. Justice Rehnquist concurring in
the judgment. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
No. 77-5549. Michael Taylor, petitioner, v. Kentucky. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Kentucky. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals of Kentucky for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Powell. Concurring statement by Mr. Justice Brennan.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with whom Mr. Justice
Rehnquist joins.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, MAY 31, 1978
723
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES.
Present: Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice
White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice.
Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
OPINIONS
No. 77–178. Willard E. Robertson, petitioner, v. Edward F. Weg-
mann, Executor of the Estate of Clay L. Shaw, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice White
join.
No. 77–380. Cecil D. Andrus, Secretary of the Interior, petitioner.
v. Charlestone Stone Products Co., Inc. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall.
No. 76–1114. California et al., petitioners, v. Southland Royalty
Company et al.;
No. 76–1133, El Paso Natural Gas Company, petitioner, v. South-
land Royalty Company et al.; and
No. 76–1587. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, petitioner,
v. Southland Royalty Company et al. On writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with
whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Mr.
Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of these cases.
No. 76–1484. James Zurcher, etc., et al., petitioners, v. The Stanford
Daily et al.; and
260-278-78-83

724
WEDNESDAY, MAY 31, 1978
No. 76-1600. Louis P. Bergna, District Attorney, and Craig
Brown, petitioners, v. The Stanford Daily et al. On writs of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr.
Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of
these cases.
No. 76–1608. Michigan, petitioner, v. Loren Tyler and Robert
Tompkins. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Michigan.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Mr. Justice
Blackmun joins judgment and Parts I, III, and IV-A of the opinion.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens concurring in part and concurring in
judgment. Opinion by Mr. Justice White concurring in part and dis-
senting in part with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
Adjourned until Monday, June 5, 1978, at 10 o'clock.
☑

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 5, 1978
725
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77–1376. United States, appellant, v. Georgia et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Northern District of
Georgia. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
Marshall would vacate and remand case to the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Georgia for further consideration
in light of United States v. Board of Commissioners of Sheffield, Ala-
bama, 435 U.S.
(1978).
_
No. 77-1450. Otto T. Bang, Jr., et al., appellants, v. Roger F.
Noreen et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Minnesota. Judgment affirmed.
No. 77-1472. Ignacio Pena, appellant, v. Southern Pacific Trans-
portation Company. Appeal from the Court of Civil Appeals of
Texas, Eighth Supreme Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77-1606. Wendell H. Russell et al., appellants, v. Cortlandt
Parker et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, First
Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77-1485. Thomas J. Hilligoss et al., appellants, v. Arthur J.
LaDow, etc., et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Indiana. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-497. New Orleans Public Service, Inc., petitioner, v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
260-278-77- -84

726
MONDAY, JUNE 5, 1978
granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further consideration in light of Marshall v. Barlow's, Inc.,
436 U.S. (1978).
No. 77–605. Mississippi Power & Light Company, petitioner, v.
United States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further consideration in light of Marshall v. Barlow's, Inc., 436
U.S. (1978).
No. 77–557. Consolidation Coal Company, petitioner, v. United
States;
No. 77–606. Francis Leo Marks, petitioner, v. United States; and
No. 77–622. Raymond J. Zitko, petitioner, v. United States. On
petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. Petitions for writs of certiorari granted, judg-
ment vacated and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
consideration in light of Marshall v. Barlow's, Inc., 436 U.S.
(1978), and Michigan v. Tyler, 436 U.S. — (1978).
No. 77-1270. United States, petitioner, v. Paul Labriola and
Thomas Contino. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Motions of respond-
ents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of United States v.
Mauro, 436 U.S. (1978).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-1005. Joan Little, applicant, v. William Ciuros, Jr., Com-
missioner of Correction of the City of New York, et al. Application
for stay, presented to Mr. Justice Marshall and by him referred to
the Court, denied.
No. D-135. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Henry Kutza.
It is ordered that William Henry Kutza, of Fort Myers, Florida, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 77–747. Walter J. Fleck et al., appellants, v. Warren Spannaus
et al. Motion of Allied Structural Steel Co. for leave to file a supple-
mental brief, after argument, granted. Mr. Justice Blackmun took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

MONDAY, JUNE 5, 1978
733
No. 77-970. Alton Sonstegard, petitioner, v. City of Kettering.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Mont-
gomery County, denied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall
would grant certiorari.
No. 77–1058. Raymond A. Helgemoe, Warden, et al., petitioners, v.
Thomas E. Meloon. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit denied. The Chief Justice and
Mr. Justice Blackmun would grant and reverse summarily, notwith-
standing the new statute.
No. 77–1407. David Kitsis, petitioner, v. California. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Appellate Department of the Superior Court
of California, County of Los Angeles, denied. Mr. Justice Marshall
would grant certiorari.
No. 77–6400. Michael Douglas Wiggins, petitioner, v. United
States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr.
Justice White would grant certiorari.
No. 77-6466. Michael H. Cassidy, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Tenth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart
and Mr. Justice White would grant certiorari.
No. 77-6470. John Eldon Smith, petitioner, v. Joe S. Hopper,
Warden. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Geor-
gia denied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall, dissenting:
Adhering to our views that the death penalty is in all circumstances
cruel and unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth and Four-
teenth Amendments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231 (1976),
we would grant certiorari and vacate the death sentence in this case.
No. 77–6589. Francis C. Smith, petitioner. v. Connecticut Parole
Board et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit and for other relief denied.
No. 77–6703. Eugene Emerson, petitioner, v. Louis L. Wainwright,
Secretary, Department of Offender Rehabilitation, Florida. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit denied for failure to file the petition within the time
provided by 28 U.S.C. § 2101 (c).

OPINION
No. 76–1726. Mobil Oil Corporation, petitioner, v. Frances Nell
Higginbotham, Administratrix of the Estate of Marshall K. Higgin-
botham, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Blackmun
joins. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or de-
cision of this case.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.
אן

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JUNE 6, 1978
745
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
OPINIONS
No. 76–1410. Joseph V. Agosto, petitioner, v. Immigration and
Naturalization Service. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr.
Justice Rehnquist joins.
No. 76-1159. Arthur F. Quern, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Venus
Mandley et al., and
No. 76-1416. Joseph A. Califano, Jr., Secretary of Health, Edu-
cation and Welfare, petitioner, v. Venus Mandley et al. On writs of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 77-452. Mobil Alaska Pipeline Company, petitioner, v. United
States et al.;
No. 77-457. Exxon Pipeline Company, petitioner, v. United States
et al.;
No. 77-551. BP Pipelines Inc., petitioner v. United States et al.;
and
No. 77-602. ARCO Pipe Line Company, petitioner, v. United
States et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
of these cases.
No. 75–1914. Jane Monell et al., petitioners, v. Department of So-
cial Services of the City of New York et al. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
260-278-77-86

746
TUESDAY, JUNE 6, 1978
Mr. Justice Brennan. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.
Statement by Mr. Justice Stevens concurring in part. Dissenting opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger
joins.
Adjourned until Monday, June 12, 1978, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 12, 1978
747
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice.
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 77-1042. David B. Terk, appellant, v. Ladd S. Gordon, etc.,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of New Mexico. Judgment affirmed. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-1185. Memorial Consultants, Inc., appellant, v. Illinois, ex
rel., George W. Lindberg, etc. Appeal from the Appellate Court of
Illinois, Third District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 77–1306. Leonard C. Jaques, appellant, v. State Bar Grievance
Administrator. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Michigan. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Michigan
for further consideration in light of Ohralik v. Ohio State Bar As-
sociation, 436 U.S.— (1978).
No. 77-1535. David L. Heilman, appellant, v. A & M Records, Inc.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-992. Billy George Hughes, Jr., applicant, v. Texas. Applica-
tion for appointment of counsel to prepare and file petition for writ of
certiorari, presented to Mr. Justice Powell and by him referred to the
Court, denied.
No. D-95. In the Matter of Disbarment of Albert Ohralik. Disbar-
ment entered.
No. 76–1694. Mobil Oil Corporation, petitioner, v. Harry Lightcap
et al. Respondents requested to file a response to petition for rehearing
within thirty days. Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of this order.
260-278-77-87

748
MONDAY, JUNE 12, 1978
No. 77-753. International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs,
Warehousemen and Helpers of America, petitioner, v. John Daniel;
and
No. 77-754. Local 705, International Brotherhood of Teamsters,
Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers of America, petitioners, v.
John Daniel. Motion of American Academy of Actuaries for leave to
file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of The Chamber of Com-
merce of the United States for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae,
granted. Motion of American Bankers Association for leave to file a
brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of The National Coordinating
Committee for Multiemployer Plans for leave to file a brief. as amicus
curiae, granted. Motion of ERISA Industry Committee for leave to
file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
No. 77–803. William G. Barry, etc., et al., appellants, v. John
Barchi. Motion of New York Racing Association, Inc. for leave to file
a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
No. 77-837. New Motor Vehicle Board of the State of California,
et al., appellants, v. Orrin W. Fox Co., et al.; and
No. 77-849. Northern California Motor Car Dealers Association,
et al., appellants, v. Orrin W. Fox Co., et al. Motion of National
Automobile Dealers Association for leave to file a brief out of time,
as amicus curiae, denied. Motion of appellants in No. 77-849 for addi-
tional time for oral argument denied. Alternative request for divided
argument granted.
No. 77-1115. Robert M. Lalli, appellant, v. Rosamond Lalli, Ad-
ministratrix of the Estate of Mario Lalli. Motion of Legal Aid Society
of New York City et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae,
granted.
No. 77-1161. Albert C. Drebin et al., petitioners, v. United States.
Application for extension of time to file petition for rehearing,
presented to Mr. Justice Brennan and by him referred to the Court,
denied.
No. 77–1202. Michigan, petitioner, v. Harold William Doran.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed herein in forma pauperis
granted.
No. 77-1254. Cyrus R. Vance, Secretary of State, et al., appellants,
v. Holbrook Bradley et al. Motion of appellees to dispense with print-
ing appendix granted.
No. 77-5781. Frank L. Rakas and Lonnie L. King, petitioners, v.
Illinois. Motion of Americans for Effective Law Enforcement, Inc.
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
No. 77-6683. Chester Wheeler Campbell, petitioner, v. United
States. Application for bail, presented to Mr. Justice Marshall and
by him referred to the Court, denied.

MONDAY, JUNE 12, 1978
APPEALS JURISDICTION POSTPONED
749
No. 77–1378. Japan Line, Ltd., et al., appellants, v. County of Los
Angeles, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. Motion
of Sea Land Service, Inc. for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae,
granted. Further consideration of the question of jurisdiction is post-
poned to the hearing of the case on the merits. The Solicitor General
is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United
States.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 77-1410. William E. Butner, petitioner, v. United States et al.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit granted.

for writ of certiorari to the Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate
Division, granted.
No. 77–1493. Gladstone Realtors et al., petitioners, v. Village of
Bellwood et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit granted.
No. 77–648. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, petitioner, v.
Pennzoil Producing Company et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted. Mr.
Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this petition.
No. 77–1465. Director, Office of Workers' Compensation Programs,
United States Department of Labor, petitioner, v. Genevieve O.
Rasmussen et al.; and
No. 77-1491. Geo Control, Incorporated and New Hampshire In-
surance Company, petitioners, v. Genevieve O. Rasmussen et al. Peti-
tions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit granted. Cases consolidated and a total of one hour
allotted for oral argument.

OPINIONS
No. 77-117. National Broiler Marketing Association, petitioner, v.
United States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice White with whom Mr. Justice Stewart joins.
No. 76-1471. Federal Communications Commission, petitioner, v.
National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting et al.;
No. 76–1521. Channel Two Television Company et al., petitioners,
v. National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting et al.;
No. 76–1595. National Association of Broadcasters, petitioner, v.
Federal Communications Commission et al.:
No. 76–1604. American Newspaper Publishers Association, peti-
tioner, v. National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting et al.;
No. 76-1624. Illinois Broadcasting Company, Inc., et al., peti-
tioners, v. National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting et al.; and
No. 76-1685. Post Company et al., petitioners, v. National Citizens
Committee for Broadcasting et al. On writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed in part and reversed in part and cases remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice
Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of these cases.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 77-1736. Albert Smith, President of the Village of Skokie,
Illinois, et al., petitioners, v. Frank Collin et al. Application for stay
of mandate or, in the alternative, for stay of enforcement of judgment
pending action on petition for certiorari, presented to Mr. Justice
Stevens and by him referred to the Court, denied.

MONDAY, JUNE 12, 1978
769
Mr. Justice Blackmun, with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins, dis-
senting: I feel that the decision of the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit is in some tension with this Court's decision, 25
years ago, in Beauharnais v. Illinois, 343 U.S. 250 (1952). Beauharnais
has never been overruled or formally limited in any way. I therefore
would grant the stay pending consideration of the applicants' peti-
tion for certiorari which has now been filed, and pending further
order of the Court.
Adjourned until Wednesday, June 14, 1978, at 10 o'clock.

No. 77-10. Exxon Corporation et al., appellants, v. Governor of
Maryland et al.;
No. 77-11. Shell Oil Company, appellant, v. Governor of Mary-

of Maryland et al.;

land et al.;
No. 77-64. Ashland Oil, Inc., et al., appellants, v. Governor of the
State of Maryland et al. Appeals from the Court of Appeals of Mary-
land. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in part and dissenting in part. Mr.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these
cases.
No. 76–1382. United States, petitioner, v. John Arthur Scott. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan with whom Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr.
Justice Stevens join.
No. 76-1040. Thomas Sanabria, petitioner, v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the First
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice
Stevens. Mr. Justice White joins Parts I, II-A, and III of the opinion.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice
Rehnquist joins.
No. 76-1200. Roger Crist, as Warden of the Montana State
Penitentiary, Deer Lodge, Montana, et al., appellants, v. L. R. Bretz
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment as to Bretz affirmed. Appeal as to Cline dismissed as

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 14, 1978
moot. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Concurring opinion by Mr.

Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
* No. 76–6528. David Wayne Burks, petitioner, v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Blackmun
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 76-6617. Richard Austin Greene, petitioner, v. Raymond D.
Massey, Superintendent, Union Correctional Institution. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Powell. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist concurring in
judgment. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

No. 77–334. First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Boston
et al., appellants, v. State Tax Commission et al. Appeal from the Su-
preme Judicial Court of Massachusetts. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Stevens. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring
in part and dissenting in part.

Bair, etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Iowa. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Justice Blackmun
joins.
No. 77–911. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Robbins
Tire and Rubber Company. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Mar-
shall. Concurring opinion of Mr. Justice Stevens with whom Mr.
Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Powell concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom
Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 76–1701. Tennessee Valley Authority. petitioner, v. Hiram G.
Hill, Jr., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with
whom Mr. Justice Blackmun joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist.
Adjourned until Monday, June 19, 1978, at 10 o'clock.

MONDAY, JUNE 19, 1978
775
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 77-1460. Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, appellant, v.
Public Service Commission of the State of New York. Appeal from
the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York, Third
Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77–6796. Medric C. Godbout, appellant, v. John V. Norton.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 77–891. Frank S. Beal, Secretary of Welfare of Pennsylvania,
et al., appellants, v. John Franklin et al. Motion for appointment of
Alan Ernest, Esquire, as guardian ad litem for unborn children
denied.
No. 77–1388. Massachusetts, petitioner, v. Charles F. White. Mo-
tion of respondent for leave to proceed further herein in forma pau-
peris granted.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 77-1715. Secretary of Public Welfare of Pennsylvania et al.,
appellants, v. Institutionalized Juveniles et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.
Motion of appellees for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
In this case probable jurisdiction noted. Case set for oral argument in
tandem with No. 75–1690, Parham v. J. L. and J. R., minors, etc.

782
MONDAY, JUNE 19, 1978
No. 77-1534. South Central Bell Telephone Company, petitioner, v.
Louisiana Public Service Commission. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of Louisiana denied. Mr. Justice White and
Mr. Justice Powell would grant certiorari.
No. 77-1548. Sheet Metal Workers' International Association,
Local No. 3, petitioner, v. Siebler Heating & Air Conditioning, Inc.,
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice White would
grant certiorari.
No. 77–6539. Richard Lee Denney, petitioner, v. Texas. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas denied.
Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall, dissenting: Adhering
to our views that the death penalty is in all circumstances cruel and
unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth
Amendments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231 (1976), we
would grant certiorari and vacate the death sentence in this case.
No. 77–6616. John Lee Layton, petitioner, v. Edwin T. Pogue,
Warden. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant certiorari.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 77–6670. Albert H. Carter, petitioner, v. Jack Roberts, United
States District Judge, Western District of Texas. Motion for leave to
file petition for writ of mandamus denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED

sion et al.;

v. United States et al.;

Kansas City;

and
No. 77–6657. William E. Conrad, petitioner, v. First State Bank
& Trust Co. Petitions for rehearing denied.

MONDAY, JUNE 19, 1978
OPINIONS
No. 77–335. Oppenheimer Fund, Inc., et al., petitioners, v. Irving
Sanders et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.
No. 77–598. The Greyhound Corporation et al., petitioners, v. Mt.
Hood Stages, Inc., etc. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conform-
ity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
No. 77–365. United States et al., petitioners, v. LaSalle National
Bank et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals with instructions to remand the case to the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois for
further proceeding in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Rehnquist
and Mr. Justice Stevens join.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 77-452. Mobil Alaska Pipeline Company, petitioner, v. United
States et al.;
No. 77-457. Exxon Pipeline Company, petitioner, v. United States
et al.;
No. 77-551. BP Pipelines Inc., petitioner, v. United States et al.;
and
No. 77-602. ARCO Pipe Line Company, petitioner, v. United States
et al. Application for an order directing compliance with conditions of
stay was received and presented to Mr. Justice Brennan and by him.
referred to the Court, it is ordered that the judgment of this Court
issue forthwith.
No. 77-1674. Fred R. Field, Jr., petitioner, v. United States. Ap-
plication for bail denied without prejudice to an application in the
District Court. See 18 U.S.C. §§ 3148, 3146; Fed. Rule App. Proc.
9(b); Unted States v. Bowdach, 561 F. 2d 1160, 1167 and n. 2 (CA5
1977).
Adjourned until Wednesday, June 21, 1978, at 10 o'clock.
Х

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 21, 1978
791
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
OPINIONS
No. 77-560. Jo Ann Evans Gardner, petitioner, v. Westinghouse
Broadcasting Company. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 76–1836. Coopers & Lybrand, petitioned v. Cecil Livesay and
Dorothy Livesay, etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals with directions to dismiss the ap-
peal. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 77–539. Zenith Radio Corporation, petitioner, v. United States.

Mr. Justice Stevens join.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

Stevens. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Powell concurring in part and dissenting in part and joined
by Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist to the extent it
dissents from the opinion and judgment of the Court. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist and joined by Mr. Justice White in
Part II of this opinion.

Northern District of Illinois, petitioner, v. Calvert Fire Insurance
Company et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the judgment of this Court. Mr. Justice Rehnquist announced
the judgment of this Court and delivered an opinion in which Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Stevens joined.

senting opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice
Marshall and Mr. Justice Powell join.

in No. 77-836 reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Judgment in No. 77-575 reversed and case remanded to the Supreme
Court of Mississippi for further proceedings not inconsistent with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

MONDAY, JUNE 26, 1978
797
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 76–1690. H. W. Berry et al., appellants, v. J. D. Doles, etc.,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Middle
District of Georgia. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the Middle
District of Georgia with instructions to issue an order allowing appel-
lees 30 days within which to apply for approval of the 1968 voting
change under § 5 and for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Powell concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Justice Stevens joins.

trict Court for the Southern District of New York for further con-
sideration in light of Hicklin v. Orbeck, 437 U.S. (1978).

OPINIONS
No. 77-5176. Jerome Franks, petitioner, v. Delaware. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Delaware. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Delaware for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with
whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins.
No. 77-444. Penn Central Transportation Company et al., appel-
lants v. City of New York et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
New York. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Chief Jus-
tice Burger and Mr. Justice Stevens join.

808
MONDAY, JUNE 26, 1978
No. 76-1621. Herbert H. McAdams, III, as Executor of the Estate
of John L. McClellan, et al., petitioners v. Allan McSurely et ux. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Dis-
trict of Columbia Circuit. Writ of certiorari dismissed as improvi-
dently granted. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger.
No. 76–1572. United States, petitioner, v. Ted R. Grayson. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for reinstatement of the sentence of the United States District Court
of John L. McClellan, et al., petitioners v. Alan McSurely et ux. On
for the Middle District of Pennsylvania. Opinion by Mr. Chief Jus-
tice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom
Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 77–262. Duke Power Company, appellant, v. Carolina Environ-
mental Study Group, Inc., et al.; and
No. 77–375. United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission et al.,
appellants, v. Carolina Environmental Study Group, Inc., et al. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the Western District of
North Carolina. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Western District of North Carolina for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart
concurring in the result. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist concurring
in the judgment, with whom Mr. Justice Stevens joins. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment.
No. 76-1310. Thomas L. Houchins, Sheriff of the County of
Alameda, California, petitioner, v. KQED, Inc., et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the judgment of this Court.
Mr. Chief Justice Burger announced the judgment of the Court and
delivered an opinion in which Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist joined. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart concurring in the
judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Powell join. Mr. Justice Marshall
and Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration and
decision of this case.
Adjourned until Wednesday, June 28, 1978, at 10 o'clock.

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 28, 1978

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice

OPINIONS
No. 77-747. Allied Structural Steel Company, appellant, v. Warren
Spannaus et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the District of Minnesota. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the United States District Court of the District of Minnesota for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan
with whom Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Mr.
Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 77–653. William Swisher et al., appellants, v. Donald Brady
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of Maryland. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the District of Maryland for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court Opinion by
Mr. Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Powell join.
No. 76-811. Regents of the University of California, petitioner, v.
Allan Bakke. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Califor-
nia. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court of California for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the judgment of this Court. Mr. Justice Powell
announced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion joined
by Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall
and Mr. Justice Blackmun in Parts I and V-C and joined by Mr.
Justice White in Part III-A. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Blackmun con-
curring in the judgment in part and dissenting. Separate opinion by
Mr. Justice White. Separate opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
Separate opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stevens concurring in the judgment in part and dissenting in part
with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr.
Justice join.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

OPINIONS
No. 77-369. Furnco Construction Corporation, petitioner, v.
William Waters et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall concurring in part and
dissenting in part with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 77–240. St. Paul Fire & Marine Insurance Company et al.,
petitioners, v. David M. Barry et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins.
No. 76–709. Earl L. Butz et al., petitioners, v. Arthur N. Economou
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals with instructions to remand cause to the United States
District Court for the Southern District of New York for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice White. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist concurring
in part and dissenting in part with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger,
Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Stevens join.
No. 76–1560. United States, petitioner, v. United States Gypsum
Company et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Stewart joins the opinion except
in Part IV. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in part.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist concurring in part and dissenting
in part. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens concurring in part and dis-
senting in part. Mr. Justice Blackmun took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this case.
Adjourned until Monday, July 3, 1978, at 10 o'clock.

OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 77-1107. Alabama et al., petitioners, ". Jerry Lee Pugh et al.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted
limited to Question 2 presented by the petition, and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals with instructions to order the dismissal of
the State of Alabama and the Alabama Board of Corrections from
this action. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
Marshall dissent. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77–929. Hollis O. Black, appellant, v. William E. Payne,
Executive Officer, Public Employees' Retirement System, et al. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California, Third Appellate District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77–1067. Los Angeles County et al., appellants, v. Associated
General Contractors of California et al.;
No. 77–1078. Associated General Contractors of California et al.,
appellants, v. Juanita M. Kreps, Secretary of Commerce, et al.; and
No. 77-1271. Juanita M. Kreps, appellant, v. Associated General
Contractors of California et al. Appeals from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Central District of California. Judgment vacated
and cases remanded to the United States District Court for the Central
District of California to consider the question of mootness.
No. 77-5541. Charles Edward Downs, appellant, v. Ohio. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Ohio. Motion for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Judgment vacated insofar as it leaves undisturbed
the death penalty imposed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of
Ohio for further proceedings. See Lockett v. Ohio, 438 U.S.
(1978).
No. 77-5708. Ellis Shelton, appellant, v. Ohio. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Ohio. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Judgment vacated insofar as it leaves undisturbed the death

OPINIONS
819
No. 77-528. Federal Communications Commission, petitioner, e.
Pacifica Foundation. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the judgment of this Court. Mr. Justice Stevens
announced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion with
respect to Parts I-III and IV-C joined by Mr. Chief Justice Burger
and Mr. Justice Rehniquist and in all but Parts IV-A and IV-B
joined by Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Powell and as to
Parts IV-A and IV-B joined by Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr.
Justice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with
whom Mr. Justice Blackmun joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
White and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 77-285. California et al., petitioners, v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
Marshall join.
No. 77-510. United States, petitioner, v. New Mexico. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of New Mexico. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell
dissenting in part with whom Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice White,
and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 76-6997. Sandra Lockett, petitioner, v. Ohio. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio. Judgment reversed to the
extent that it sustains the imposition of the death penalty and
remanded to the Supreme Court of Ohio for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the judgment of this Court. Mr. Chief Justice
Burger announced the judgment of this Court and delivered an
opinion with respect to Parts I and II in which Mr. Justice Stewart,
Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr.
Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens joined, and with respect
to Part III in which Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Powell and
Mr. Justice Stevens joined. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun con-
curring in part and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Mr.

820
MONDAY, JULY 3, 1978
Justice Marshall concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Mr. Justice
White dissenting in part and concurring in the judgment in this case
and in No. 76-6513, post. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist concur-
ring in part and dissenting. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 76–6513. Willie Lee Bell, petitioner, v. Ohio. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio. Judgment reversed to the
extent that it upholds the imposition of the death penalty and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Ohio for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the judgment of this Court. Mr. Chief Justice
Burger announced the judgment of this Court and delivered an
opinion in Part I in which Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White,
Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Stevens
joined, and in Part II in which Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice
Powell and Mr. Justice Stevens joined. Opinion by Mr. Justice Black-
mun concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Mr.
Justice White dissenting in part and concurring in the judgment in
this case and in No. 76-6997, ante. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice
Rehnquist. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
The Chief Justice announced the following order of the Court:
"All cases submitted and all business before the Court at this term
in readiness for disposition having been disposed of,
It is ordered by this Court that all cases on the docket be, and they
are hereby, continued to the next term and will commence hearing oral
arguments on the first Monday of October."
Adjourned to the time and place appointed by law.
